While still packed this past sat, we managed to snag a table immediately. Beer is excellent. Food is very good. We had the muscles and frites for 2 for $24. I think this was a fair price although both of us left semi hungry. Muscles and frites were as good as most of the places  I ate when in Belgium.
Great! Went for lunch s few weekends ago. Food was delicious. We all enjoyed our meal. I want to go back on a nice day and sit outside.

I've been to Hopleaf many times and have always had a great experience. Good selection of beers, friendly bouncer, yummy food, great dessert. Went tonight at 10:15pm on a Friday (kitchen is open until 12pm) with a group of four looking to grab a few drinks, some dessert, and catch up. The main bar area was loud, so we made our way back to the dining area. We were told by the host that because we were ordering dessert (from the dining menu) and not a meal, we wouldn't be allowed to sit back there where it was possible to hold a conversation at a reasonable volume. There were multiple 2, 4, and 6 tops open and nobody was waiting for a table. When I asked why something on the dining menu didn't "count" as enough to be seated in that section, he let us know there was a section around a corner on our left that we could sit at. I could understand this policy on a Friday at reasonable dinner hours; however, at ten o'clock at night with more tables available in the back than in the bar area we were being directed to, especially when we were intending on ordering items ON the menu. We got turned around trying to find the section he referred us to and a woman approached us to explain that the tables we were standing by were also not available unless we were ordering dinner. Again, I asked why dessert and appetizers and drinks didn't count if they were on the menu, and was met with a vague, perfunctory reiteration of the fact that we were not allowed to eat at these tables. I promptly left and don't intend on going back. Ran into a friend outside who was equally as baffled about this policy as we were. He recommended Lady Gregory's down the street, where service was far friendlier.

These guys have an amazing beer selection. Seriously, it will take you a while to decide from all the different options you'll have.  The staff is always attentive and the back room super cozy and cute. Their food is great, especially the mussels. Seriously, order the mussels.

Beer haven, a tavern feel with bricks and tackers from across the globe everywhere. Mussels for $13, delicious, excellent beer selection on draft and in bottles. A must go to for a beer lover in Chicago- no reservation needed.
Good food but higher end prices I much liked the place back in the 90's when they served yummy food right in the bar area,and it was not soo pricey.
Beer selection, amazing. I had the brisket sandwich that I saw on food network and it was okay not great and it didn't look the same.

Consistently great. I've been here a few different times and every time I've had a stellar food experience. All of the items are delicious, from the scallops appetizer to the CB&J sandwich with a side of mac and cheese, to the endless selection of beer.  Of all of the things I've tried, my favorite is the mussels dish. It is by far the best bang for your buck--mussels in aromatic and flavorful broth with just enough bread to soak up all of the goodness. Oh and of course, a cone of fries.  This place is a gem. Will definitely keep coming back for more.

Major letdown! I had this place bookmarked for so long. Maybe my expectations were too high what with all the rave Yelp reviews. Great beer list and very friendly service but the food was a letdown. The salad was just ok, my goat sloppy joe was dry, mac & cheese just average, mussels were very good, and the fries...oh excuse me, the frites, were the best part of the whole lunch. Very cool place and I really liked the huge umbrella shading the patio. One of the drawbacks of sitting at the bar is that overtime someone opens the door you get a blast of cold air (at least on the day I was there). Get a seat in the dining room or in the huge room next door. Leave the kids at home. You must be 21 to enter.

This place has become a destination for me that delivers solid enjoyment.  The bartender on the first visit was a French guy who understood the role and appreciated people who knew how to order without being stupid.... I enjoyed the bar immensely.  But on a trip to the bathroom I saw the glass enclosed kitchen with the wrap around area to sit and eat.  This is now the only place I feel like sitting.  Watching a crack kitchen crew run like a well oiled machine while enjoying good food and beer is my kind of evening.  The charcuterie plate and the sausage plate are gifts from above and must be tried.  Not all the food items are great, the stew on waffle was so-so and the waffle was boring as hell, almost Leggo.  But overall the quality of the menu is very good, and the beer menu has a deep bench, though slanted towards European styles.  Its a great place, and I will be working my way further through the choices as I get a chance.

Decided to try Hopleaf after my BF raved about this place for years. Finally, after a long day of shooting photography with friends, we decided to give this place a try. This review is only on the quality and quantity of the food.  Hopleaf gets two stars for its subpar portion sizes and quality of food. For what we spent we could have had a way better meal at another place down the street. Go to Hopleaf for the beer do not try to eat here you'll leave this place hungry.

Heard that the lobster curry mussels were amazing and I'm a craft beer guy so I decided to finally stop in. Carded at the door, then sat at the bar. Jacked Asian dude (James?) was very nice and responsive even though the bar was pretty packed. Mussels were great, 2nd best I've ever had. Extensive craft beer selection although the menu seems oddly arranged (prob not going to be considering a local Pilsner and a local DIPA, would be better if arranged by style). Only complaint, and actually for me was pretty big, there's a single entry, not a double like most Chicago bars (many just set up a double entrance during colder months) so whatever awful windy whether is outside will come gusting in every minute. Was quite annoying to sit in a cozy warm bar and have 30-40 degree wind blasting in at least once a minute for my hour stay. It also slams pretty loud. I want to give this place 5 stars, but with cold wind blasting on me as I speak and a loud door slamming every few seconds I just can't.

A friend and I shared mussels & frites and catfish hoagie. The mussels here are super popular for a reason. They were delicious. The waitress suggested we order a different side for the catfish  hoagie since the mussels also came with fries so we substituted onion rings, which were so good. Everything was very good and the portions pretty large because this was more than enough food for the two of us.

Went on a Wednesday mid-afternoon, small crowd but filled up by 5.  Obviously extensive beer list, Belgian heavy of course, but great descriptions make the choices easier even if you don't recognize the names. Price for beers range from about $5 to $12 and up.  Something for everyone. Took a while to peruse the beer menu and decide on smoked wings appetizer.  The place smelled of smoked meat so that probably helped us decide on the wings. 4 big 3 part wing pieces. Juicy, great smoked flavor.  Little birdy feathers still on places, but the skin was so crispy that didn't allow anyone down.  There are a few sections in the establishment. We entered from Clark St. Into bar area with booths and a few tables. You go to the bar to order everything yourself in this section and we were fine with that. Beyond that was a seating area where it was more formal, you are seated, etc. And on the south side of the building there was another bigger seating area. We had goat bbq sandwich and chips and got thumbs up on that. Portion size was adequate. I had the brisket. So tender. Frites in a big pile, awesome, awesome garlicy aioli!! The rye bread as also good.  We also had the duck Reuben and frites. Yum, succulent!  The menu is small but I think that allows them to concentrate on the flavor details. Options change from lunch to dinner.  I can see some people having a problem with a slightly less pedestrian menu but we enjoyed it. Would eat here again, definitely. And great drinking beers.

I love Hopleaf! I don't frequent only because of it's location, but every time I visit I am reminded of how much I love this place! Their draft beer list is untouchable! if you are looking for a craft brew from anywhere in the US and beyond this place is for you. Their food is also incredible- the mussels are a must and the french fries are so crispy and delicious and come with a garlic aioli! yum. I have also sampled the catfish sandwich and the duck reuben, both are tasty. Although they do not take reservations, Hopleaf is HUGE and likely accommodating to groups. will be coming back and bringing friends or family next time!

Yes! Finally after living here for over 7 years I finally went to Hopleaf & can't wait to go back. The drink menu is impressive. The food menu is even better! The decor was homey, darker, wood burning stove, all brick. Gorgeous. Very cozy.  I prefer hard ciders and they had a lot of those to choose from. We shared the charcuterie plate which was good and then interesting. I ordered the catfish hoagie and the garlic mayo was perfect. Thin fries came with. Beef and vegetable soup was fantastic as well.  We all shared a campfire dessert that had pickled blueberries on it. Yummy!  If you're in Andersonville go here!

Came here on a Wednesday night with a big group of friends and we wanted to grab a few drinks and have a good time and that is exactly what we got! There was about 8 of us but we were able to find seats together. We all ordered a variety of draft beers and I ordered a cider called the Zombie Killer. I'm really not a beer fan but wow, I was impressed by the Zombie Killer. The cider had a nice tangy but sweet flavor that wasn't too overwhelming. The bartender, who was an angel, let me sample some ciders before I purchased anything and he was very knowledgeable.  I would recommend this place if you're looking for a chill place, good drinks, and quality service!

We tried Hopleaf because my wife is allergic to soy products and their menu says they use canola oil for frying instead of soy; also, it's close to her work, and it's beer-oriented (we were disappointed in the Radler so were continuing our search for a Eurostyle beer gastropub). We were very pleased! They served us right away even though it was 6 pm on a Friday. It's a vast restaurant. The place smells great with a fragrant wood stove going. Our server was very pleasant and efficient.  In addition to a few delicious dark beers, we had onion rings, the catfish hoagie, and a smoked porchetta special (super tender and well-brined, Bristol, take note!). Everything was delicious and chef quality. We'll be back to try the mussels and duck. Thumbs up!
I've never ordered food here, but the atmosphere and the beer selection are both great. It's my go-to "lets meet up sometime for drinks" bar!
Atmosphere is very dark but I would imagine this is the theme they are going for. The beer menu is awesome but the food in my opinion is just ok. I had the duck ruben and it was absolutely awful!!!!
Always wonderful! I love the mussels and onion rings! Great craft beer selection. Great for any occasion - date, friends, outdoor patio, happy hour, lunch, and/or dinner!

I like that  they have a variety of ciders for me to chose from and I really liked the CB&J sandwich. Its worth a visit if you're in the area. I look forward to enjoying their outdoor seating when the weather warms up.
Hopleaf never disappoints: good food, great beer, nice ambiance. It can be crowded at peak times but it's worth the wait if you have time. The mussels and frites are superb.
You have to get the fries with the garlic aioli. Oh my god. Service was good, beer was good (I mean, it's beer) but that aioli...  We had some other food too but I only have eyes for the aioli.

Hop Leaf is a great gastropub! This is one of my favorite places in the city for a casual night out. I have never been inside of a place with such an array of options. They are constantly rotating their draft selection offering excellent brew options from all over the world. They also have a great rotating selection of favorite options from local breweries. My favorite sandwich there is the Toasted Nueske Ham sandwich. The aioli for the fries is also incredible!

Fascinating beer list with a good number of smaller ounce options (yay). Very nice bartenders. Tolerable noise level for the number of tables and chairs. Duck Reuben is a substantial sandwich of tender and juicy thick-cut duck slices, a thin melty layer of cheese, and the right amount of sauerkraut wedged in between two perfectly buttered toasted slices of earthy, almost chocolately dark rye bread. The only flaw was the seeming absence of salt from the meat, but that was easily remedied by the salt shaker behind the bar. Every bite of this sandwich was savored, and it came with a large handful of excellent thin fries and an awesome garlic aioli. If you ask the staff nicely, they'll pack your leftover fries with an extra tub of this awesomely garlicky sauce.

Great atmosphere, beer, and not too long of a wait. Cauliflower appetizer tastes great but isn't really described well. It's like a buffalo chicken ball with ranch, delicious. Somewhat small serving. Salmon is really good.  Cooked well with a flavorful and salty skin on top, heart of palm and a mustard like dip with mushrooms.  Mushrooms have a pungent taste and smell.   Duck roast was... For those that like game!  A bit fatty and chewy at parts.  I'm sure this is one of the better cooked duck meals out there - I'm not a game fan so I won't comment.

Love this place!  It's huge, but on slower nights or slowers seasons like January and Feb, it still has a small neighborhood feel to it.  Great cheese, meat selections, and their staff is kind, and super helpful.  A great wine selection to, went on a sunday night just to chill and catch up with a friend, and he was amazed at the beer selection, and their menu in general.  Can't wait until the weather becomes nice again to enjoy upstairs and their patio.  For me, I love HOPLEAF in general; but especially because I got the last PALM they had in house!  Glad this is in my neighborhood, and wouldn't want it any other way!

So, Hopleaf is a family owned business. I always try to support family owned businesses. I'm upgrading my prior review to four stars (so now I've given them five stars, two stars and now four stars!) because the owner reached out to me and followed up with his staff to determine what happened the night I was there and the food was awful. He corrected the situation without hesitation. I still recommend Hopleaf as the best beer bar in Edgewater.

This is my happy place. I love everything about this place. The beer menu is substantial, don't just look at the draft selection. The menu rotates and there are off menu additions. Everything is good. Haven't had a bad thing yet. I just ate the steak with fries, go medium, it's basically medium rare. That was a tasty mother fuckin' steak. Came with a garlic butter for the fries. I made room for both. The wife got the duck and wished she got the steak. I'm inclined to agree; the duck was fine, but over cooked, I would have expected it rare, hence I docked a star. So I just had the duck fat donuts; it's like duck stuffing served with ice cream. How novel! I'd say go for it and try something creative! The environment is awesome, exposed brick, a second floor, and multiple rooms. Go straight to the back and sit by the fireplace.
Delicious food (mussels are the best), great prices, kind waiters, and unique beers. If I lived in Chicago, this would be one of my favorite places.

Ok I was debating between 3 or 4 stars.  I gave this place 4 but I wAnted to give them 3.  The food was a new experience for me since I am so used to eating the same flavors and spices in most of the restaurants but since this place is a bar.  I gave them 4 stars for creativity and the use of a lot of condiments new to my taste buds.  It was very different but overly too pricey for my opinion.   Our server made a few mistakes to our order which was a plus because we had to remind her she had forgotten something.  Either she was new or was over worked but hardly made it back to our table.  For desert we got were wrong order but the manager saw the mistake and he gave us our original desert which we enjoyed. No I will not come back.

Great atmosphere and staff. Great bar food! The CB&J IS really great and an excellent value here.  All the ingredients are well balanced and are greater than the sum of their parts. What a surprise! The homemade chips were perfection. The mac and cheese was perfect too. Just creamy enough, a little bit of a kick and crispy on top with no oily separation. The kale salad was refreshing and different than any other kale salad I've had before.

The beer selection is of course outstanding.  Have more ciders now too.  Ambiance is great on both the old and new parts of the bar.  I just wish they would update their food menu.  Even their mussels.  We were there about a year ago when they had a special curry mussel and that was good.  I wish they would do more of that.
Best mussels I've had in Chicago. Loved the draught wine and service was fab!  Will definitely go back.
It has a great reputation. The drinks are on point. The only catch is that it can be kind of boring here

Recently hit up Hopleaf again and it's still doing what it's doing (in a good way).  The meal was tasty, as I went with the Mussels in beer (the mussels are better at Vincent's just up the street). The fries though are a reason enough to go there. I'm one of those weirdos that likes the European mayo with fries thing. Some fries and beer is well worth going to this place.  It's a staple in the city and the neighborhood. You definitely need to make it here if you haven't already.

Hopleaf is charming. Used to go when I lived in the city. I was just planning a trip with friends to come this weekend. They don't allow children. That is crazy. I have one grade schooler who would not disturb anyone. The blatant discrimination is really upsetting.

After reading all these great reviews, my husband and I were excited to try this place out. Our waiter was totally miserable and clearly unhappy to be there. We ordered the duck Reuben with mac and cheese, for a $3 up charge, and the mussels. The food was under seasoned and bland. We didn't even finish it. The poor customer service continued as we were never even asked how our barely touched meal was. My husband works in the industry and was stoked to try this joint but it was beyond disappointing. NEVER. AGAIN.
Patience is important. Great food and an amazing Belgium focused beer list. Kitchen is fast and utilizes a great front-of-the-house support staff.

!!!!!!! SAVE THIS BEER HOUSE!!!!!! I have been frequenting the Hopleaf for a couple of decades now.  It was an oasis for great beer lovers when you couldn't get anything like that on the far north side.  I also frequent the Map Room and the Long Room.  Unlike these places, the hopleaf has been creeping into a corporate darkness where customers are only #s.  Last night I went there with four friends and we ordered two rounds of beers ranging from great Belgians to the super hopped IPAs that they carry.  Each beer was flat.  When we told the bartender after the first round, he shrugged his shoulders.  When we told the bartender after the second round, he completely dismissed the question.  I then got a round of different bottles with hopleaf "pint" glasses for the table.  We poured and within a minute our beers were flat.  we figured that it must be the detergent they were using and not the lines or the beer itself.   Not to hard for a few of us non industry folks to figure out.  but this place couldn't be bothered with the question, not to mention the answer.  The other, and more corporate bullshit thing that we found out when we poured the 12oz bottles into the hopleaf "pints" was that they are using cheater pints!!  They only hold 13.5oz of liquid.  There is not a 13.5oz pint in any country you slime bags.  So by pinching 2.5oz from each of our beers they get a bigger bottom line.  Like a fucking suburban sports bar!! These cheater pints are actually illegal in Michigan.  The thing is, the hopleaf actually prints that they are selling us 16oz in the menu!  you might have great beers but you sucks when it comes to respectability!!  You really need to change to get me back.  Not that you need me.  Your place is full all the time.  But that begs the question: with all those customers, why did you need more $.  You reek of greed more than beer, you should be ashamed of that.  The hopleaf WAS a symbol of quality and integrity.  I can't imagine how your disrespectful ways translate in your kitchen, grossly I'm sure.  I will drive a little farther to the Long room and the Map Room to be in a place where I know they care about the drink and the drinker.

Outstanding beer selection and beer-friendly gourmet food pairings. The venison appetizer was excellent and the duck breast Reuben was one of the best sandwiches we've had. Warm atmosphere and very good service. Try this place. You'll be back.
Everything was fantastic. We had mussels, brisket, Mac and cheese, and a Reuben, not to mention some awesome beer. We highly recommend it if you are at least 21.

Hop Leaf has always been one of my favorite places to grab a beer.  They pride themselves on their beer and cider list, and it never disappoints.  It's a great bar with a great atmosphere.  It isn't too rowdy, and it gives you a chance to sit and talk with your friends.
Fun pub with some interesting beer selections. Very chill vibe. We had an awesome hybrid of a mead and a cider with Michigan Cherries.

Thanksgiving weekend in Chicago is generally dead. In a good way. Nobody around, which means...no waits at typical hotspots like Hopleaf! Erin J. and I came in around 8:00 on a Saturday and were given the option to sit at the bar that overlooks the kitchen. We nabbed the seats and it was pretty awesome to see the chefs at work while we dined. Hopleaf is known for their beer list and they did not disappoint. I started with an awesome ginger peach cider and also enjoyed a 5 Rabbit brew I had never tried! Our server was extremely knowledgeable about the draft list and was helpful in our decision-making. To start for dinner, we shared the charcuterie plate and fall Cobb salad. Big warning! The charcuterie plate is definitely for adventurous charcuterie eaters! We enjoyed most of what we ordered, but some of the items were a bit out of our comfort zone. To follow, we shared the mussels and mac n' cheese. Both were a hit, the mussels for one was definitely enough for us to share. While tasty, the dish was extremely salty and the bread that accompanied the dish was too hard to eat. These are basically my only complaints about Hopleaf. Mac n' cheese was creamy, tasty, and super rich. I highly recommend sharing a bunch of things so you can try multiple items! Overall, Hopleaf lived up to the hype. Truly enjoyed the warm atmosphere, impressive beer list, variety of menu items, and solid service. I can't speak to the long waits on typical weekend nights, but seems as though going at off-hours and in small groups will absolutely reduce the wait time.

Excellent beer list, and perhaps the best beer-drinking environment in Chicago.   The tap list is more than enough to keep the serious beer consumer interested, and there is also a very deep bottle list. Belgian frites and mussels (get the Belgian-style) are the very best you'll find.   I believe the compare favorably to what you'll find in Brussels, and I speak from personal experience.    The other food here is unfortunately hit or miss.  The sandwiches are soggy. The expansion into the space next door, as well as the outdoor patio in the summer, has made Hopleaf a realistic group option, even during busy times.   Back when this place was smaller, you had to carefully time your visits to avoid the crowds.   Not really a problem anymore. If you are with a group and plan to order food, get a table in the back room for a calmer experience.   If it's cold out, ask for a table near the fireplace.

I have been to the Hopleaf perhaps fifty times in the 8 years I've lived in Chicago. I was surprised to see they have only 4 stars. After reading many reviews, I have some advice for the disgruntled few: You're doing it wrong. 1. They I.D. everyone. Everyone. You are not a special snowflake, get your i.d. out.  2. They do not allow anyone under the age of 21 to enter. Not 6 days old, not 20.9 years old. Just know this. You may not like the policy; go somewhere else. 3. This is a bar first, then a restaurant. Do not come for a fine dining experience. Come in a group of no more than 4, show your i.d., grab a space in the first room for the most authentic experience, or continue to the "new" bar on the first floor and score a booth (my preference.) There is no table service in these areas, which means you can sit alllll night and no one will rush you out.  Go to the bar (have someone stay behind to hold the table.) Order a Kwak, a Maredsous, and two other beers/wines/ciders. Order mussels for two and a CB&J with fries instead of chips. Order the Brussels sprouts. Now go sit down. You are welcome.
Great beer list. CB &J is one of my favorite sandwiches. Normally has a long wait but highly recommended!

Service can make or break your impression of a restaurant which accounts for Hopleaf's dismal rating.  Believe me, if no stars were allowed, they'd deserve it.  What Medicare card carrying person on this globe looks like they should be carded for age at a bar; especially one that primarily just moves beer?  Answer: None.  But that is exactly what happened a few hours ago when this creature asked to see my ID when I stopped in for lunch.  No I did not take it as a compliment because I don't believe it was intended as one.  The message was people who look like you aren't welcome here.  I gave no verbal response to the man and just did a "how dare you" about face, left and went up to Lady Gregory's.  A much better venue that was completely pleasant from beginning to end.  Hopleaf could do the world a favor and disappear.

This was our first time here and it won't be the last!  We had the scallops to start - delicious.  I ordered the CB&J and my fiancé ordered the brisket.  My sandwich came out with the bread a little dark, but I didn't think twice - it was great.  Then our server came by and said the chef saw how the bread of my sandwich turned out and was making another one!  I had already eaten one half of the first one!  Within minutes, they brought out another sandwich and said it was due to the fact the first one wasn't up to their kitchen standards.  Of course, that sandwich was excellent as well.  I can't forget to mention the amazing beer selection.  We will definitely be back!

I loved the wood burning fire stove in the back since it's one of my favorite smells in the winter. We lucked out and were seated right next to it! The food is solid and they have every type of beer imaginable here. My Duck Reuben was tasty and I surprisingly didn't need ketchup for the fries since the dipping mayo that comes with was decent. They let you sample the drinks before you commit. I enjoyed the Virtue cider and one if their Belgian beers La Trappe Puur which came in the purrrfect glass. Order the Kwak beer and you won't be disappointed in the presentation of it! This is a solid restaurant with the most unique and biggest selection of beer that I've encountered in the Midwest.

Found this place thanks to Yelp. I had to kill a few hours while my kid attended a concert at the Aragon Ballroom.  This place is less than a mile away.  Parking is in the street and for 2 hours max.  You enter the restaurant through the bar, and head up a ramp in the back to be seated.  My first impression was kind of a dive bar feel, but that changes quickly when you get to the back.  We were seated right away and welcomed warmly by Val. They have a great selection of draught beers and bottled.  The menu is eclectic, but everything looked intriguing.  My wife had the Duck Rueben which she raved about. I had the brisket which was pretty good (think corned beef, not BBQ). The Frites were very good as was the aioli that accompanied them. I got a side of Stilton Mac and Cheese. It was unique and very good.  The next time my kid wants to attend a concert at the Aragon, I'll say yes, just so I can go back to Hopleaf!

Six words: Incredible beer menu, delicious brisket sandwich Hopleaf is the kind of place that I wished I was a regular at, mainly because they have the most incredible beer menu I've ever seen. Four densely packed pages of beers of all different varieties with the most incredible descriptions. This is the kind of place where you could learn so much. If only it wasn't an hour away by bus. If only! I was here with a bunch of friends because it was the midway point between all of us. Two lived in Evanston, one lived in Uptown, and I live in Noble Square. Midway. We made reservations in advance and were seated once everyone arrived. And then we were given the most incredible beer menu ever. Pages upon pages. The waiter came by multiple times and we just couldn't make up our minds. He gave us recommendations. We'd ponder them. And still no decision. We were horrible - I'm so sorry we were so indecisive. I ended up picking a beer at random - the BOM Brewery Triporteur Full Moon. I wish I had saved the menu description - it basically described the beer as a witches brew - with something about mountains, and dark and something else. It was the most delicious beer I've ever tried and I don't think it's on tap anymore.  Dinner was slightly easier. I went with the Grass-fed Brisket mainly because it sounded good and because I had never had brisket before. No idea what it was but it was amazing. It was normal sandwich sized and was on two slices of bread. But the meat inside was moist but not too moist. And incredibly flavorful. I practically inhaled my sandwich. And the pomme frites attack on my plate was so delicious. Most of plate was covered in them and I still finished them all.  I definitely want to go back. I definitely will go back.

This place remains one of my favorite spots in Chicago. Great food, genuinely friendly staff, unpretentiously beautiful space, and interesting food options. Get the mussels and fries ("frites"). Mussels for One is actually great for 2 or 3 people. Only complaint is that a lot of the food is too salty for my taste.

Really good place. I've been here a few times and love the steak and the desserts especially.  I would not go when it is very busy - the food comes cold and the service is not amazing. But most of the time it is a wonderful place with great food and service!

Let me start off by saying that Hopleaf is truly a great place to go no matter what you are in the mood for. If you want to go on a first date (or 100th date), grab a truly nice lunch or dinner, grab a beer with friends, get drunk with friends, or wander in alone at 1pm on a Thursday looking for salted meats, Hopleaf will not disappoint. I met Mark (he cuts the meat at Hopleaf) last week. Turns out that he lives across the street from me (small world) in Ravenswood and told me I have to go try the Charcuterie at Hopleaf. Thanks for the baller tip Mark.  Does anyone else know the feeling of being "in" a meal? That's my test for how the meal was. Was I "in" it? Were the flavors, textures, ambiance, service and drink so wonderfully harmonized that I was able to escape this temporary and mundane existence by going "in?" Oh yes, I was "in" this Charcuterie experience all right, and I hope one day you get to dive in too. Just make sure that you don't eat for at least 30 minutes before entering the beer soaked waters.  I asked my server, who was perfect by the way, to please have the kitchen choose which 3 meats I would try. (Note: Just start doing this guys, it makes SO much sense.) I, however, chose Three Floyd's Zombie Dust (they have it on draft people!) as my drink of choice. I thought it would pair quite well. I was quite right. For my board, the kitchen selected Tonno Di Maiale (olive oil cured in ham), the Pork Belly Rillette and sliced duck (it was off menu, and I forgot exactly what it was called). The presentation was beautiful, the portions perfect and the tastes all grabbed my shirt collar. Even the mustard was good. The Tonno Di Maiale was so tender and just the right amount of salty that I almost ordered more. Good lord was it good on toasted baguette with mustard and a quail egg. The pickled beats were also a nice addition.  NOT TO BE MISSED are the white wine mussels. They are very good (although freshness/flavor fluctuates) but the sauce at the bottom is so god damn good I don't even know what to do sometimes. The bread they give you is some of the best bread you'll get in Chicago restaurants and it soaks up all that deliciousness so efficiently I wanted to find out where the bread baker lives and go rake his yard (not a euphemism) for him.  I also have to plug the salmon: wonderful. Guys and gals: You need to just go try this place, plain and simple.

Nicely conceived and deftly executed food, presented by a staff with absolutelly no training in Michelin-quality service.  I'm sorry, just really repellant, cold bartenders.  Bartenders behind the counter should be the portal to possibility-- I'm ready to spend $150 bucks here for myself alone, depending on your advisement.  But at Hopleaf, there were no recommendations, no invations to alternative options, no inside scoop on the menu items, or special ingredients or seasonal dishes,  or what they're really proud of.  These bartenders were almost mute.  They acted like they were looking over their shoulder to see if anyone saw them steal that money from the register.  Almost suspicious and paranoic.    Took them seven minutes to ask me if I wanted to see a menu.  And then they didn't return to me for a full fifteen minutes.  No joy or relish in the food pairings.  I ordered a cheese course, and they gave me a slab of a single cheese.  Clearly someone alone would want a selection of cheeses, not just one slab of one type of cheese.  They didn't care or even ask me.  No knowledge of wines (I know hops is their speciality, but still.)  No upsell. No welcome, no introduction, no friendly conversation with customers.  No explanation of the dish as it's being presented.  No knowledge of the cheese maker.  No knowledge of how the soup's prepared.  They're curt, abrupt and retreat to their cell phones.  Watch them-- it's almost comedic.  Severe deficiency in server experience and in need of professional training.   Patrons are here because of the Michelin recommendation and expect that level of service, even raucous, bouyant casual service.    If you want a gastropub experience that will bring tears of joy to your eyes, try Longman where you leave with an empty wallet and a firm belief that food and beer can save the world.

Decided on Hopleaf because I know they're always well stocked with Zombie Dust. It has a sharp balance of citrus hops that puts a smile on every sip. Its brightness paired very well with my charcuterie. It was a trio of nduja, pork belly rillette, and tasso bacon.  Njuda is a spreadable spicy pork sausage that has a mild spice with a bold pate like flavor and consistency. It paired best with the whole mustard on toast. The bar in the back was a bit loud with a big party near us, so I couldn't hear the entire plate. The berry on the pork belly rillette cut the fattiness of the pork belly and helped bring out the pork flavor. The star on the board was the tasso bacon. It was soft, fatty bacon that had the essentials of crispy bacon with strong smoky flavor, but instead melted in your mouth. Once melted, the bacon flavor shines through and bliss arrives. The bacon tastes so right. I noticed the tiny quail egg, but didn't hear that it was pickled! It had a med-well vinegar taste and worked out really well, because it cleaned my palette of that greasy feeling. The plate was well organized and would definitely have again. This isn't my first time really enjoying their food and would gladly come back.  Side note: On my way out, there was a sign above a beer fridge that said "Off-Menu Specialties. Please ask your server!" How did I not see this before?!? I guess i'll find out on my next visit.

The tap list is incredible and that should be the main reason you're here. You shouldn't need me to tell you that and you probably didn't.   But we also got food here (you've no doubt noticed that I spend too much of my time eating in bars) and that is worth a few brief comments:  Some of the items seem like a perfect match to a beer hall with pretensions -- the sandwiches, the brussels sprouts sides, and probably the other sides too, though I didn't try them.  Other items seem to be longer on pretension, shorter on beer hall -- steak frites, rabbit confit salad, short ribs, etc.   Some of the items in the second category were great (the rabbit confit was a big hit), but most were disappointing and I would be inclined to stick to the safer bar fare here.  With one caveat -- most of my table was annoyed by the fact that our french fries were all lukewarm.  (I didn't actually mind, I was just grateful that they weren't limp and soggy.) Still, did I mention the tap list?
Had the maple duck and the venison, along with Kwak and depth-charged double bastard beers. Everything was cooked perfectly, and everything we hoped for and more. Will definitely be coming back.
Good stuff - all the way from the beer to the food. Hell, even the wine is tasty!  Great place to get toasted on a lazy Sunday afternoon!

The taplist speaks for itself.  I've thoroughly enjoyed some Off Color Apex Predator during my recent visits. I'm writing because of the mussels and fries.  These are why we can have good things.  I spent the last visit swimming with the fries and bread in the Belgian wit mussel broth and entering into a state of enlightened delirium.  Seriously, try it and you will have the same reaction.   The venue is crowded, but it seems like if you hit it at the right time you can get service.  Customer service at the bar has always been very friendly.  I'll plan to return every time I'm in Chicago.

GREAT BEER SELECTION AND SUPERB FOOD!! Bartenders and servers are actually knowledgeable in regards to the craft brews and meal preparations! I'll be back for the monkey bread and any one of the seasonal small batch beers. Love this place, it's a must visit place while in chicago!

I was excited for my first trip to Hopleaf! I had seen it reviewed on a lot of Food Network shows and I only live a block away. I got the mussels for one, which comes with frites! The mussels were on the small side but there were an abundance of fries to make up for it (the sauce that comes with them is pretty tasty!). Everyone at our table enjoyed their meal and their beverages. They have a very extensive list and their menu changes frequently so we all had a lot of fun picking out things that you can't find at most restaurants. The dessert was SUPER tiny...I was a little disappointed. The "cake" was smaller than a muffin top and the scoop of sorbet was the size of a ping pong ball. For $8 I expected a little more. This place is pricey, but like I said, you're not going to find most of these menu items (with these kinds of awesome twists) in most restaurants. It's an experience and I definitely recommend it.

Hopleaf has been a go-to place for years for me. It has the best beer selection in the city, it's open everyday of the year, and the food compliments the beer just right. I partook in the monthly fried chicken special today, and it was well executed with a flavorful crust and moist, tender inside. Past delights of mine include the duck reuben sandwich and the Cashew Butter and Fig Jam with Raclette Cheese sandwich served with pomme frites. Late closing kitchen (12am) and bar, I suggest dashing there.

Terrific beer selection! Top notch! This is the only bar I know in the city where you can get a bottle of Devotion or Rare Voz. They have a humongous collection of great beers! It's a great place to study, hang, meet people, celebrate, or just chill. Food menu can be a bit too much for my taste (organ meat), but adventurous.  The vibe is local, relaxed, pleasant, and warm.

3 girls shared the Belgian-style mussels (for 2) and the CB&J sandwich. Mussels are on the small side but fresh. the broth was only okay...I actually wanted to try the lobster based broth but gave in to what was considered popular. The fries and the aioli was addictive. The CB&J was rather tasty...not something I would have ordered on my own. The Stilton mac and cheese that accompanied it was a bit overwhelming though (the cheese had a strong goat/sheep cheese flavor). The beer selection is extensive. I am not much of a beer drinker ...I like the less hoppy wheat beers usually. Upon our waitress's recommendation, I ordered the Tripel Karmeliet which as not hoppy and it came in it's own glass.   Great place to grab a bite on a Sunday at 5:30pm as there was no wait and perfectly located before catching the Neo-futurist show nearby.

I feel like a jerk writing this review because everyone loves it here, but I've been here a handful of times just hoping it's going to be as good as all the other reviews say it is.  The food has never blown me away.   Mussels are ok, the charcuterie plate is pretty tasty, and the sandwiches have just been ok.  I feel like it's overpriced and it's just more hype than anything.

Honestly...disappointed and trying to keep as "objective" as possible with this review.  I have constantly been told that the mussels at Hopleaf are "the thing" to get, and I had really high expectations.  So, when I finally got a chance to go there recently I ordered the mussels.  The broth was good, and the bread was good, but the actual mussels themselves were definitely over cooked, and all seemed very withered and dry.  I know this is the Midwest, and that I shouldn't have particularly high expectations for things like mussels, but after hearing how great it was at Hopleaf and being presented with what I had... I know I've had better in the city at other places.  The fries that came with it were also really not that spectacular, they were fine, they were fries after all, but nothing that really made me want to go back.  Definitely not somewhere I plan on going back to visit any time soon. Three stars because service was fine, the patio was nice, and honestly I might have just been there on an off day.

Oh hopleaf, I love you. I can always count on you for a delicious, refreshing cerveza. Just so you know, the Belgian flag on your menu is backwards in half the Belgian beers. But that's ok cause I'm more of an american beer kinda gal.
Good beer list. The restaurant part can be hit or miss. Duck Ruben is very good, the pastrami, not so much. Service can be spotty too.

Wow! What a wonderful restaurant. From the eclectic and expansive beer menu to the similarly quirky and vast food menu, there is something for everyone here. I've had several beers and two meals here. My duck reuben was my favorite meal. The flavors were outstanding and utterly original. I also enjoyed my ham and cheese sandwich. It was very tasty, but not as original as the reuben. And the fries...oh the fries. They are worth every individual fry...and boy are there lots of them. They do not go skimpy on the portions, especially with the fries. The staff were friendly and the huge venue is fun to explore. Each room has its own unique vibe. I can't wait to return in the future!

One of my favorite places to go! My girlfriend and I always get the mussels for 2 and then have fun ordering beers we've never tried before off their enormous menu. The bar staff is always friendly and will recommend you something whenever you ask. It is a popular place so is always pretty busy, but they have a ton of room, so you can always find a seat. I recommend going in the middle of a crisp fall day and sitting in a booth with a friend all afternoon, trying their menu and any beer that looks good.

This is my go-to spot in the neighborhood. It's never dead empty, which is a testament to how much they do right.  The beer selection cannot be beat. If you are a beer geek or know one, then Hopleaf is the place to go. There's an overwhelming amount of stuff on tap, and even more available in bottles, including some rare beers. They specialize in Belgian & Belgian style beers, which I absolutely love.  The food is also top notch. Hopleaf does a great job of providing a certain level of consistency in menu items - there are always mussels, there are always salads - but they tweak the offerings to fit with what's in season. For mussels, there are always two options: a Belgian style & a special style, with the special being a rotating & unique offering that is never repeated. Currently, the special is lobster, and it might be the best type of mussels I've ever had. It's like a lobster bisque, but with corn & fennel, some heat...just tons of good flavors.  The charcuterie trio is out of control. I recommend the nduja, duck liver mousse, and the pork belly rillette. The onion rings are another great bar snack.  The service at Hopleaf is always on point & servers are happy to help you navigate the massive beer list.  I come here a few times a month and am continually delighted by Hopleaf. What a great place!

Lots of good reviews here so permit me to provide some perspective.  I ate here last night for dinner with my beautiful wife. We had all the classic hopleaf favorites like the Frites aka fries, the duck Reuben, the sausage trio, and of course the famous clams.   This place is always busy and the manager of the place clearly makes a point to get people in and out.  A bus lady asked us at least 4 times if we were finished with our fries when there were clearly many fries still in there.  The fries by the way came cold.   The famous clams.  Still tasty but way too much salt in the broth and very little meat on these things. The duck Reuben was good.  A little unhealthy with a slathering of butter on the bread but clearly the safest most popular choice here for $13.  It's also a cheaper option. The sausage trio was boring and amounted to perhaps a sausage and a half maybe. The lamb sausage was the best and the most un-hot dog like. The huge German beer for $6 was the highlight.  So 3/5.  It's still a cool place but some of that magic I remember is missing.
Never disappointed here. Great beer selection. Love the patio. Brisket sandwich with fries is to die for. So are their charcuterie and mussels.

Given Hopleaf's perpetual hype and quoted two-hour wait times, I was so, so ready to dislike this place. And actually, the first two times I went, I did! I chose two Saturday evenings (unwise) and spent most of the time in the hectic first room with the sour-smelling bar (equally unwise). But as soon as I chose some weeknights to head into the restaurant area for after-work drinks and a quick dinner, Hopleaf's stengths and charm were on full display. The beer selection is always varied, exciting, and new, and the food menu is reliably curated. The CB&J is fried to a different degree every time I order it, but that's actually fine since it's literally impossible to ruin cashew butter, fig jam, and brie. Side salad is so good that they should offer it as a full meal. The service is hit-or-miss in terms of warmth, but efficiency is their strong suit.
Get a beer or two or three. Great variety of beer and a fun place to meet up with friends. Bartenders were attentive and funny.

Been here a few times for both lunch and dinner. They have great mussels and there sandwiches are well done. There bar can be kinda unwelcoming with the crowd that's there but the upstairs bar is really neat and inviting. It can get busy bit it's a nice lively environment to have dinner and a drink.
Great local bar. Always run in to old friends and wind up making new friends. Hopleaf gots something giing, please dont stop.
Very cool gastropub. Delicious mussels.  The fries and the smoked fish are great too but a bit too salty.  Four wines on tap! The pinot was actually pretty good.

I've been to this place a few times and I always forget to leave a review while I'm there because I can't stop talking about their mussels!! Mussels for 1 or 2 -- They serve it with two different broths (I always get the Belgian one with onions), it also comes with bread (which you can dip in this delicious broth) and a generous side of fries.  The fries are delicious. They're not too thick and seasoned just right.  The onion rings are very, very thin (which personally I love!). I'm not in the habit or ordering fried food but someone else at the table ordered these and I ate about a quarter of the plate -- that good!

Fantastic restaurant! Great selection of Belgian and other beers, great food (though you have to fast for a couple of weeks to deal with the calories...). One HAS to have the fries with the aioli sauce, and the Toasted Nueske Ham sandwich, which just MELTS in your mouth! I see lots of people ordering steak and another favorite: mussles...

Always friendly staff, great selection of beer and cider on tap. Food is always good, try the frites and muscle's. The back patio or in the front open window is the best spot on a warm afternoon when an adult libation and tasty snacks are needed. But be warned it can get REALLY busy and crowded at peak times and you will have to wait for a table.

What can I say, this place is amazing. This is the first place I try to make it to whenever I'm in Chicago.  It has a world-class beer list featuring some very rare beers. For example, they have Atomium Grand Cru which I have otherwise never seen outside of Belgium, and carry geuzes and other less commonly seen beer styles. The food menu is also quite inventive and fun, and the indoor and outdoor spaces are very pleasant. It gets pretty busy at times and so hard to get a seat, but everything else about this place makes it well worth it.
My favorite beer bar in Chicago. The Atomium on tap is awesome. Just wish they would change the taps more often.
A great bar for both beer and food. The beer selection is huge and their homemade head cheese is a must have. Even if you think head cheese is gross, try it and you will change your mind.

This has to be one of my favorite places for beer I've ever visited. Really cool, classy city feel; especially when the garage door windows are open in the summer. Their beer menus are detailed and organized, which make things easy for the consumer. Each beer has it's own description and after visiting a few other brew houses, I appreciate that. Ha! Food there is unique but delicious nonetheless. The fries are awesome!

A beer enthusiasts dream. I travel weekly for work, and this has been my favorite place so far. A Belgian inspired menu (I got the delicious duck ruben- I saw some guests with tasty looking mussels frittes), and you know it's going to be great when there's a section on the beer list just for Trappist ales. I'm going to keep this review short and sweet and say that if you truly consider yourself a beer enthusiast, you need to make some time to stop in here, no matter what.

Y'all, Hopleaf is truly one of my absolute favorite places in the entire country. I sincerely mean that without any sense of hyperbole or white girl hysterics. TLDR:  Lovely Belgian-ish and non-Belgian gastropub.  Beer. Order mussels, pomme frites, or my favorite, the duck reuben. More beer. And now, long pros/cons... PROS: ----Beer list is crazy.  Sheer quantity combined with expertly curated selection. 70ish constantly rotating taps, a bazillion bottles (though I've never ordered a bottle). The tap list has at least 1 entire page of just Belgians, and 2+ pages of other beers. Most importantly, even more impressive than the sheer number of beers is the wide variety of selection. Lots of local beers, lots of non-local beers, many standard favorites kept constantly on the menu (Zombie Dust, Left Hand Milk Stout, Bell's Two-Hearted, etc are almost always on tap), lots of different style varieties, always several unique and rare beers, and the list goes on. I can't imagine any enjoyer of beer could possibly come here and not find something they are interested in. Even beer newbies won't be too overwhelmed as they describe each beer in words on the menu. ----Don't want beer?  At least 5-ish ciders are always on tap too, as are a good handful of wines (yes, wines on tap). Liquor is available. ----Great food! Seriously, this place would be legendary on its beer merits alone, but they also have great food. I recommend the duck reuben or mussels and frites. I'm surprised my entire body hasn't turned into a duck reuben yet. Some friends like the brisket sandwich but I found it dry. Charcuterie, if that's your thing, is excellent, and has only been slightly surpassed in my experience by The Publican (which is no small compliment to Hopleaf). ----The space itself is cool. It's a huge, winding sort of place with 2 bars, a back patio, an upstairs loft, and lots of brick and wood. Both the front and back bar sections are bar service only, and the seating everywhere else is table service. Walls display steel beer signs from around the world, and lots of neon beer lights (cool ones, not tacky ones) hang in the windows. Douchebag/DudeBro quotient usually pretty low, even when very crowded. I think this is because it's 21+ and because of what food and drink is being served. It's also in Andersonville, one of the north side's best neighborhoods. Lots of funky stores and independent businesses line northward up Clark Street, where Hopleaf sits. CONS: ----Can get crowded on Friday/Saturday nights. Because it's such a sprawling space, during the day it's always super relaxed, weeknights aren't uncomfortably crowded, and I've been here on plenty of weekend evenings that don't get too crazy. But I must be fair and say that on a good number of weekend nights, it can get pretty packed. ----Not the cheapest? This shouldn't even be a point of contention, but I know it matters to some folks. You can get a few of the same beers elsewhere for a dollar or so less, and yes, the food is more expensive than bad pub grub or, even worse, Chili's. But you get what you pay for, and here you pay for selection, quality, and deeply knowledgeable service. IN CONCLUSION: One of the best places in Chicago and also one of the finest beer bars in the country.

I've been here a few times now, twice for drinks and once for food (and drinks). They have a HUGE beer list (both on draft and bottled/canned) with good descriptions, so there is a little something for everyone.  The waitresses are helpful in giving suggestions and describing the beer (and food) as well.  They also have a really nice back patio area surround by fresh herbs (which I assume they use in some of their dishes). Overall a great spot in Andersonville - will definitely be back.

A great menu, but I've gotta say that the mussels were pretty small this time.  For a great menu, much of which I've not tried, Hopleaf is wonderful.  An amazing choice of beers, and servers who are all smiling and helpful.  Within the first 5-10 minutes, I was greeted by no less than 3 of them asking if they could get me anything while I waited for my friend to arrive.

I was finally able to bring my roommate to Hopleaf after raving about trips that my boyfriend and I had taken there for their amazing beer and food. We arrived around 8:30 on a Sunday evening and ordere some beers from the bar at the front while we waited on a patio table to open up, which took about 10 minutes. Their beer list has something for everyone and I suggest taking a chance on a new one you haven't had, because they're all good. Any Ballast Point, Deschutes, or Three Floyds will automatically rise to the top of my list, and they're always on draft here. Once seated, our waiter let us know about the specials for the evening, including the cheese and charcuterie offerings. We got the charcuterie plate with nduja, duck rillette and headcheese, and the server was so kind as to add the fatback spread on the house because I got so excited when he mentioned it! The plate also had deliciously buttered bread, boiled quail eggs, mustard and pickled turnips. Could've eaten this forever had it not been for the amazing codfish spread we also ordered. It was creamy and light and paired perfectly with the pickled vegetables and greens served alongside it. One day I may make it past the appetizers and small plates here but I would be happy with any dish set in front of me at Hopleaf. This place deserves every star and more.

Great beer, great food, great everything..... the wait is not so great, but if you're okay drinking while you wait, then it's really not that bad. The mussels are fantastic. The fries and onion straws are amazing. The beer selection is omg-amazing.

Always a great atmosphere! The new addition is not quite "new" anymore, but it really opens the place up and accommodates for more people and how busy this place cam get. And thats because people come and stay, chat, have a good time!

I had to order three times because the waiter didn't know what the kitchen was out of. I get that places run out of food, but for the waiter to not know, more than once, which choices were off the menu is a little frustrating. I finally got a salad and wasn't impressed. My boyfriend got a brisket sandwich and it was okay, but the fries were the best part by far. The atmosphere is awesome, and the guy at the door was super welcoming and helpful. Very cool concept going on in here for sure.  Overall I'm not sold. Maybe we came on an off night, I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and try it again, but I'm not in any hurry.
Good food but service in back is difficult. Understand that it's not table service, but impossible to get to bar and order.
Great food and huge beer list. Visiting Chicago and this was recommended to us. If your looking for hard to find beers, ask for their off the menu beers.
Not much to say except for that I have the most amazing experience here every time I come here. Very accommodating staff.  Great beer selection.

I love everything about Hopleaf, except the staff, which is surprisingly unfriendly and unenthusiastic. The ambiance and food are top notch, just wish they'd invest in some hosts and servers to match. Update and star downgrade: went in for dessert and coffee tonight with my parents (ages 77 & 81) and the very chilly hostess would not seat us in the restaurant, despite the fact that there quite a few empty tables. She directed us to the bar, where it was extremely cold and we had to order dessert and coffee from the bartender (and ate with our coats on). I peeked into the restaurant a few times while we were there just to see if the tables were perhaps being held for reservations, but nope, plenty of empty tables. Was hoping to show my parents a good time while they visited Andersonville, but this was quite a disappointment.

I don't know why I waited so long to come to this place. I live just around the corner and everyone I know raves about the food. For some reason, I just went for the first time recently and I'm kicking myself for getting mediocre food and beer from other places in the neighborhood for so long. I went on a Monday night and there was no wait. I'm told that there's often a long wait but maybe that's just on the weekends. We were seated immediately at an upstairs table overlooking the back patio. This place is really huge inside. I had no idea how big the space was from the outside. It's quite deceptive.  Our waitress was very helpful in deciding what to order. I forget her name but she was awesome! I had the special--fried chicken and waffles with Kwak. I love that they do beer pairings with their food. I love that Kwak was used in the fried chicken. It was a great combination and it should be on the regular menu. My husband had the CB&J and it was decadent. It's a cashew butter and fig jam sandwich grilled with raclette cheese. My visiting mother had the steak with herb butter. That herb butter is like crack. I wanted some on everything. In short, don't spend three years living in Andersonville without trying this place!

That was not a good experience. After waiting 15 minutes for a table -- which was VACANT the entire time (they just wanted to make me wait) -- I waited 30 minutes for my food to arrive! Got the duck reuben, as so many recommend. The "pommes frites" were flat BURNED. BURNED. Sandwich itself was greasy and skimpy, with the bread either dried out or overcooked (or both), with thick chunks of meat -- nothing like the thin, moist slices I saw pictured on Yelp.  Waiter didn't check to see that everything was OK until I was almost done eating. p.s. these were not "Belgian style" frites, or french fries. I ate frites several times in Belgium, and EVERY time they were thicker cut -- as least twice as thick -- as these pitiful skinny sticks. And, of course, the ones I got in Belgium weren't BURNED.

Thank goodness for the expansion. At night, this place is crowded and loud. Good food and large selection of beer. Most of the time, you seat yourself and go order food and drinks at the bar.  What I really love about Hopleaf is that in the daytime or before the dinner rush, it feels like a casual coffee shop where you can meet up with a friend and have great conversations, sit and read, work on a paper, or just hang out. But instead of coffee, you get any beer you want.

Pros: awesome beer selections and knowledgeable bartenders. Cons: food! This past Friday my boyfriend and I ordered bacon flavored brisket sandwiches and they tasted like overly salty corned beef! Also, we both had food poisoning for 48 hours within 2 hours of eating here. Bottom line: drink here. Do not eat here!

Loved loved the place!! Excellent Belgian beer selection and great food :) The place is beautiful with red brick interiors and high ceilings.. The order was perfect and hence comes highly recommended: CB&J sandwich (if you are looking to try something different- this is perfect, it's sweet and savory with an excellent side of Mac n cheese); Beer: Off color- Apex something (fruity n hoppy perfect for summers); desserts: flourless chocolate cake with macadamia nut toffee bar and basil creme...  Definitely looking forward to our next visit!!
Great beer selection, a menu that isn't just your routine bar food, and amazing service. What isn't there to like about this place! Try the mussels, or the side of mac and cheese. They are wonderful!
Amazing drinks and amazing staff! The beer list is massive and the bartender was able to give me recommendations based on my taste. Pommes frites made for the perfect snack!

Ah, Hopleaf: where have you been all my life?? If you're a beer nerd, you must come here. If you hate beer, come here and I promise you will find a beer you like (or, can at least tolerate). The list is extensive, and represents excellent geographic and style coverage. As for the food, it is DELICIOUS. If you like duck, get the Duck Reuben: slow-roasted duck on marbled rye. While I wouldn't normally love the idea of throwing cranberry cream cheese on my reuben, it really works here. The onion rings are pretty tasty as well, though don't expect big ol' rings. They look sort of like what French's onions would look like if they weren't crispy. The aioli on the side is delicious as well. This place was on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives, which always makes me skeptical of whether or not a place will actually be good, but rest assured, it was! I can't wait to come back next time I'm in Chicago. NOTE: NO KIDS ARE ALLOWED
Probably my favorite beer list in the city. The duck reuben is my go to order when I eat at Hopleaf. I also just discovered they have a back patio since.

I popped in right after a flight into Chicago, and we were seated right away and the service was prompt the entire time we were there.  We did feel rushed, but it was past 10pm on a Thursday and I'm used to the friendly and more laid back vibe in Austin so I won't hold it against our waitress.  They have a solid beer menu (draft and bottle), and I was pumped to try 3 Floyd's Zombie Dust so nice job on getting some local brews on the menu.  I love trying brisket outside of the state of Texas as it usually prepared different which is a nice change of pace, and the brisket sandwich was different which was good, tasty for the first few bites, and then bland after that.  I tried to mix it up with the fries and garlic aioli as well as the beer, but it just didn't do it for me.  I'd like to try it a second time or try something else on the menu.  Overall, great ambiance, cool building with a patio, tons of beer options, and an average brisket sandwich.

Amazing space, very versatile from the neighborhood pub frontage, the dinning space with signage in the back and then diner setup to the side. The service was prompt and attentive yet not stuffy or over bearing. The Pork Belly app was flavorful and well presented in small precut mouthfuls. The Blue Corn Grit Cake appetizer was unique and complimented the Pork Belly well. The Prawn dish was not overly generous but well seasoned yet not too spicy. The real winner was the Fried Chicken special. Perfectly cooked with a great light corn/bean salad. Very creative. All in all, the extensive beer menu (Zombie Dust ftw) and great, creative food compliment each other so well. Love this place.

This has to be one of the best bars ever! The service and clientele was friendly. The beer list is insane! I was avoiding beer the night I went though (full from dinner). I was more than pleased with the wine. They had some decent wines available and the pours were crazy generous! We have friends that live nearby and will absolutely stop after dinner from now on.

Wow what a place, hidden gem! I'd definitely  say to get the marinated olives as an appetizer (these are the meatiest, juiciest olives ever). The burger was mmmmazing...probably on my top list in Chicago. We here on a Thursday night and it was packed, BUT they do use the 'nowait' app so if you want to reserve your place in line from home, I recommend doing that. I'll definitely be back!

I love/hate Hopleaf. It's is top notch for European beer selection. Get the Kwak, it's delicious, 8%, and comes in a really interesting holster thingermajiger. That said, their food is sufficiently greasy, but somethings just a little off.  Like their brisket sandwich. They claim it's brisket, but the thing is clearly corned beef. Like thin cuts of cured red meat, not like the Jewish Mom's brisket I grew up eating about once a month - in Florida! That's crazy, brisket should really be a cold weather meal. But I digress. The manager came over to reassure us that the meat that looked and tasted like corned beef was definitely brisket and that we were super dumb for claiming it was corned beef. But we did assure her that it was damn good corned beef, and were actually happy we got it since we like corned beef better than brisket anyway, so cudos to the chef, so maybe just call a it corned beef and call it a day? She hated us. Can't win em all.  But I've been to Hopleaf for drinks probably 25 times over the past dozen years, and it's an awesome bar with delicious beers. Come here to get Belgian schwasted.
Food was great! Loved the CB+J. Nice beer selection. Had a large group here for vacation and they Wouldn't split our check. Spent a while breaking it out ourselves. Left a sour taste in my mouth

Unfortunately Yelp doesn't allow you to give zero stars, but that's what Hopleaf deserves. They completely ruined a birthday celebration with their terrible customer service, despite the owner Michael personally telling us he could accommodate our large party of 13. A 30 minute initial wait is always fine, but when the hostess team consistently tells you it's going to be 45 minutes more for two hours, no one is happy. Being rude and snippy didn't help either. On the plus side, $5 beer isn't a terrible deal...

Whoa, how have I not written a review for Hopleaf yet?! Hopleaf is my favorite place to go in the Andersonville area. Sure, this is quite a trek from my place in the 'burbs, but I will not pass up an opportunity to come here. It's about a fifteen-minute walk from the Argyle red line stop. Depending on what time I have gotten off the stop, I have felt varying degrees of safety. Sometimes, it feels totally safe, other times not so much (I'm generally not comfortable being approached by strange people being asked for money, getting hit on, etc). Anyway, Hopleaf has a lot of seating, which is a good thing because this is a popular destination for a lot of people in the area (obviously, as well as people from farther away). I've been here on weeknights and on the weekend. I've never had to wait to be seated, which is incredible. On weekends, however, I would recommend trying to get there for an earlier dinner (latest 6 PM) or a later dinner (think 7:30 and later) to avoid the peak dinner times.  There's seating at the bar, downstairs, upstairs, and on the patio. I've sat upstairs, downstairs, and on the patio, and all have unique atmospheres that I enjoyed. I have ordered the same dish every time I've been here and I haven't been able to convince myself to order anything else off the menu because I'm so obsessed with the CB&J, which is basically a grilled cheese with cashew butter and fig jam. It is completely OUT OF THIS WORLD! Sometimes, I dream about this meal. Every time I go there, I tell myself, "Okay, I need to learn how to make this myself" but I've never been able to recreate it. I don't care if you eat meat. This meal is just fantastic. Oh, and it gets better. The CB&J also comes with amazing macaroni and cheese, plus housemade chips. It's all incredible and very, very filling. I am usually perfectly stuffed eating maybe 60% of this meal.  My dining companions have really enjoyed their meals, too. Also, the beer list is great. The presecco is also great. Just...come to Hopleaf. I promise you won't be disappointed!

I went to Hop Leaf with my two sons both 20 years old and I was surprised and insulted that they would not allow me eat with them anywhere in the restaurant because they have a special liquor license and asked us to leave. They have seating no where near a bar as well and we just were going to eat.  The place is cool and has great beers BUT WHO DO THEY THINK THEY ARE!

Michael has a solid operation here. It's an anchor in A'ville that we've been coming to for over 10 years. Rotating taps with a fresh menu of what's on offer each day. A little wine for ya' whinos out there too. Speaking of wine, the mussels in white wine are apparently the bees knees. I wouldn't know since I'm devoted to the brisket sandwich. Layers of thin sliced, juicy layers of brisket on rye with a smattering of seedy mustard and a side of addictive frites. Bypass the hostess stand and head to the second side of the bar for more open seating. You can almost always find a spot there, even when the front bar is crowded. The place gives a lot back to the community too and they do t have a TV in sight. Gotta love Hopleaf.

My wife and I love Hopleaf and visit several times a year.  The menu always has something interesting and you can't beat the beer selection.  The 5 star rating is also for the atmosphere which is relaxed, come as you are, this is a perfect place to kick back, have a nice meal and enjoy drinks long into the evening.  Since they have expanded the dining area there is often no wait for a table which is a nice plus.

Went because we saw an episode of DDD and craved the brisket.  Good but not amazing.  What was amazing was the CBJ-- cashew butter, fig jam, and morbier cheese on a sourdough bun.  Possibly the most delicious grilled cheese ever.   Plus zombie dusk beer on tap? Crazy.

Overall: Solid food, good atmosphere, and tons of drinks make Hopleaf great! The good: The food is all interesting and tastes great. The portion sizes are good. Food comes out quickly and hot and fresh. There is a lot of beers and drinks to choose from. The seating and patio are plentiful. The bad: Service was slow. Our table was too small for 5, after we tried combining tables and getting denied being able to do so. Check took a very long time to come after asking. Prices get a little expensive. Atmosphere: 8.5/10 Service: 7/10 Food: 9/10

Great place and environment. It definitely says Chicago out loud. Their selection of draft beer is wide and they have a lot on tap. My recommendations for beer include: -Regular: zombie dust (IPA), -Light: krankshaft, wine: les vignerones. No TV's but classy place.....staff is very friendly.

It's no secret I like a good craft beer.  And when I am looking to try something new, you can't go wrong at Hopleaf. Expansive rotating draft list. Expansive bottle list. Incredible vintage bottle list. The food here is as just fantastic as the beer.  Stop in and try it.  The food, the beer, the atmosphere, all make for a fantastic experience. Don't miss out!

This is one of the best beer bars/restaurants in all of Chicago, hands down! My friend and I went to Hopleaf on a Friday night around 9 for dinner and drinks. We only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. The building itself is really neat. It's a huge space with tons of different rooms on two floors and an outdoor area as well. Lots of cool memorabilia on the walls and exposed brick. Hopleaf is known for their Belgian beers so my friend and I each had two different ones of their draft menu. Everything was great! You really can't go wrong beer wise and our waitress was also very helpful in making suggestions. Foodwise we ordered the CB&J sandwich and the Duck Rueben sandwich. Both were really good! The CB&J is a creative take on a classic PB&J and grilled cheese while the Duck Rueben was one of the more more unique sandwiches I've had. The Reuben came with fries and garlic aioli, both delicious. Hopleaf is a must-visit for beer lovers and a great place to take friends and family to get away from all the tourist traps downtown!

I write this as I sit here waiting for my friends... I'm pretty picky on beer, as I don't normally drink beer.  Mark, one of the bartenders asked what I wanted.  I was overwhelmed by the variety of beer and had a brain freeze. He asked a course questions and figured out I like fruity beers.  He poured me one to try, and it was good. I said it worked, but he asked if I wanted yo try more. I hesitated, but decided I should.  Next thing I know, he comes over with a full glass of beautiful golden beer. He said something along the lines of "This is the beer for you", with confidence.  He was absolutely correct! It's the 5 Rabbit, and I love it!

I've been to Hopleaf 5x and I have to say that now on my 5th visit that this place is awesome. Bartenders have always been super nice, helpful, and the food has always been killer. The beer list is ALWAYS tops. Love this place and will always stop here when I visit my hometown.

I have to say I have heard numerous things about Hopleaf. Ive lived 5 minutes away for two years and never made my way in until today. I won't go again. It was disappointing as everyone has always praised the restaurant, saying how good the mussels are, as well as many other items.  We ordered the small mussels to start which were ok but nothing more than that. At least it comes with fries to make it somewhat worth it. There wasnt much flavor to the mussels and broth. We both ordered a brisket sandwich which was a joke. It came on untoasted, dry bread no larger than a 5x5 slice of bread. Meat, mustard, bread. Nothing more. The mountain of fries on my plate made me chuckle. It was literally 3 helpings worth, which made my joke of a sandwich appear even smaller.  The bus boys are overly aggressive, reaching over and grabbing things before asking if you are finished. Our server never once asked how the food was, even as he gave us our bill. Service is half of the scene. The food could be amazing and the service could suck and I wouldn't be back.  Im sure since this is such a popular restaurant, whoever reads this review will just chuckle. Im not the typical foodie who thinks its all great. Im in the culinary scene and see what works and doesn't. And perhaps I just came on an off day, but I probably won't be back to find out.
Great food, great atmosphere, great drinks. Not too pricey! Very god place.

This was my first time venturing away from the CB&J, and it was well worth it. I was interested in pairing an appetizer and salad as a meal, but I wasn't sure about the quantity: whether I would be ordering too much food. My server wasn't super helpful about the sizes of the salads, which I thought strange. I went ahead and ordered the Spence Farms Blue Corn Grit Cake and the Smoked Atlantic Cod salad. They came out together, which was what I wanted, and the quantity was absolutely perfect. The grit cake was large and the cod salad was tiny! Both were extremely delicious, with amazing flavor combinations. Super fresh, super creative. Memorable dishes. My husband had the Fried Catfish Hoagie and his only complaint was not enough fish. He kindly shared his Pommes Frites, which were the best fries (and aioli) I've had in ages. Really nice. We shared the Flourless Chocolate Cake for dessert. The cake was fantastic, but I could have passed on the myriad toppings and flavors (too much fruit for me). We always love the beer selection. A very fun place to go, any time of year.

Very cozy, several separate areas to eat in or just drink and chat.  We chose to eat at the bar and the bartender was fast, friendly and polite.  I had the CB&J and it was fantastic.  They also have a large selection of awesome beers.

This is the kind of place you wish was in your 'hood! I am so sad it is not... An amazing beer list, a great wine list (go figure) and terrific food. 5 star all around. Went with friends on a Friday and had a 6:30 reservation. Reservations are a must as this place is hoppin! Just be warned you will not be seated unless your entire party is there. And since it can get crowded, if your friends are more than 10 minutes late, they can give away your table. So show up on time people! The place is divided into 3 areas. A front bar that feels more like a local dive bar, a back room that feels more like a restaurant and then the back bar that is more open and more brewpub (this is where we sat). Beer list is ridiculous. The night we went they had Zombie Dust on tap which is like finding a needle in a haystack.  We started with the mussels and the fries which I was going to get for dinner but glad I didn't as it was big enough for 5 people to share!
