Settled on the Tilapia sandwich w/lemon pickles, butter lettuce & gribiche sauce and the wife had the CB&J on sourdough; house-made cashew butter, fig jam & raclette cheese, pan-fried; w/stilton mac-&-cheese & house-made potato chips. Both were absolute winners.  The only small (and it is tiny) complaint was the desert. I guess because the food and beer was so excellent and the desert was just very good, just a tiny letdown. But overall nothing to worry about.  Skip desert and save more room for beer!
Fantastic food! Duck Ruben is great & so is the beer selection. 21+ at all times so not good for children.

I was disappointed with our experience here.  Maybe our expectations were too high.  I thought the mussels were just ok.  They did not blow me away.  The beer selection is great though.  The duck ruben was nothing special either.  I think what made the experience worth 2 stars was the service. We went on a Monday for lunch and it was not crowded, yet our server was very impersonal and would leave for long periods of time. The greeter had to take our check because the server never returned. We should have sat at the bar.  The service would have been better.  We won't be making it back here.

Came here with my gf and her parents for dinner and this place is amazing. The inside is a lot bigger than I thought, it has two floors and three big rooms and an outdoor patio. If you like beer then this is the place for you. The beer menu is huge and there are great descriptions for each one that'll give you a very good idea of the beer you're drinking. We started off with the charcuterie plate and we got the chicken liver mousse, headcheese, and the pork belly rillette. The chicken liver mousse was the general favorite and it had a very smooth taste with a nice and mild liver flavor that paired really well with the toasted bread that came with it. The headcheese was very nice as well with a nice rich porkiness to it and pops of carrot in between. I got the grass fed brisket sandwich with onion rings and it was incredible. The beef just melted in your mouth and the onion rings had minimal batter but a nice crunch with a sweet onion flavor. For beer I got the Atomium which came in a sweet looking goblet and it was really smooth with a mild fruity aroma and taste. Absolutely coming back here to try all the beers and more brisket

This place is worthy of its great reviews. In my opinion, it's the one place in the city I would definitely take out-of-towners to and it's definitely the best place in the city up north. I'm partial to the duck reuben and mussels, which are worth the visit alone. Very unique food items, and everything we have tried has been excellent. They also have what might be the best beer selection in the city (though it's disappointing they removed Delirium Tremens from the draft list). The outdoor patio is great when the weather allows but the atmosphere inside is awesome too.

One of the best bars in Chicago for sure. Fantastic beer selection --try the Kwak while you're there. Their restaurant part is great for groups. I'd recommend this place more for groups and friend gatherings, as it tends to be rather loud and crowded most nights. It has a very fun atmosphere, delicious food and a wide range of drinks. Oh, and, they have one of the best French wine selections in the city, bringing wine from some rather fancy Châteaus (and affordable, too!).

A-ok says it. Decent food. Not bad, but I've had many way better places. So the macncheese was decent, but nothing stood out. It was a bit boring as far as macncheese goes. The duck reuben makes this place worth visiting. Its pretty good.

Absolutely my favorite restaurant-bar in Chicago. There are five different seating areas, each with their own vibe letting you pick the one that's best for what you're looking for. When you come in its a pretty normal pub style bar, a little loud maybe, so I have never sat around there. Going through there you arrive at the restaurant, with two-story windows and a fireplace. The food is fantastic, I really recommend the Belgian style mussels (they just introduced a new style but I don't believe it could get any better) and the duck Reuben, which is surprisingly delicate for a Reuben. Only complaint I might have about the food is that its a bit too salty (especially the fries) but when you're a beer or two in you'll appreciate it. Next room (still on the first floor) is more of a hipster bar feel, I believe this is the center focus when they bring in new beer/breweries. Upstairs there's another pub like area but this one is a little quieter than the one by the door. Last up is the second food area, on a balcony above the hipster bar. Its a good space if you have a large party because the first floor food area is usually pretty busy. Short story, its food-beer heaven.

I've been here many times over the years. It's walking distance from my brother's place and he's definitively a regular. Simply put, it's a cool place with great staff, a fantastic beer selection (they have a bunch of Belgian styles) with a ton of places for seating. In fact there are about 5 or 6 different areas for seating and each have a slightly different vibe from one another. We came last night with a big group and sat outside. The weather was perfect for it. I've had some really good and interesting beers in the past. On this most recent visit I got Brasserie Dupont sprl's Avec Le Bon Voeux which I highly recommend. It's worth the aroma alone. I also got Dark Horse's Sapient Trip Ale.Their food can be hit or miss. Some hits are their mussels and their duck rubean and both items are staples on their menu which changes from time to time. Last night I got the Tecumseh Farms Smart Chicken Two Ways. It's an oven-roasted airline breast, crispy confit leg, with ramp chowder purée, glazed baby carrots, hasslebeck potatoes & bacon/freekeh gremolata. I think it was the best of the entrees. The Wood Grilled Duroc Pork Chop sounded good, but it was one of their misses. It was lacking in flavor. Plus, and this may be the first time I every say this, it was cooked too rare. We've never had a bad time here. It's always fun and we ran into some other friends here by chance. It's definitely a local place, but worth the drive if you don't live near by. Especially if you're a fan of Belgian beers.

Let me start out by saying I'm a big Hopleaf fan,  it's a great place,  vibe, excellent beer selection and great food. Went for brunch just when they opened last Sat and it seems they weren't firing on all cylinders yet.   The soup selectons were both tasty, yet Luke warm like the service.  The coffee was awful,  served in a glass mug, was so weak you could see right thru the cup and it was so bitter your face cringed.  The main course our smoked meat sandwiches were not memorable or worth the $13 whatever we paid for them.  Hopleaf is capable of much more and much better.  I've had great meals and great times there.  As loyal customers and fans,  we have high expectations, which weren't met this time.

Decided last week's amazing weather was the perfect day to visit their outdoor beer garden and celebrate our visit to Chicago and my friend's law school graduation We were not disappointed! Very chill/laid back place with knowledgeable staff and an insane beer list! I will say they predominantly cater to belgian beers but I LOVE belgian beers so it didn't affect me too much! I have about 700 distinct checkins on untapped and this place had at least 25 beers I had never heard of or tried and I was very impressed that all of our belgian drinks came out in the brewer specific glass--nice touch! My husband got the mussels and frites --he said both were really good, I can only attest that the fries were perfection--so crispy, well seasoned and not a soggy one in the bunch! I got the brisket sandwich and it was really moist and just fell apart as you ate it The side of beans I got were OK I will say the Mac n' cheese we ordered to share came out cold which was a bit less than desirable but I was there mainly for the beer and hanging out with friends Will definitely return if we ever find ourselves in Chicago again NOTE: they card everyone who enters the beer garden so make sure you don't leave your IDs at home
Really great place. Good food, lots of drink choices. We will definitely go back!
We went four times there, including with friends. This is the best tap selection in town with great foods. The restrooms are clean.

I'm here about once a week. It has a great drink selection and we can always find a seat (two large rooms, plus two bars). I've also been here for a poetry reading, which was located in a spacious room upstairs. I'm not a fan of the food, but that's just because I'm a picky eater - my non-picky friends love it! Overall, great casual atmosphere and the staff is always attentive and friendly.

I drink a lot. It's not exactly a problem yet because I still have a job but my wife and kids left me a while ago and I think my liver is failing. But anyways that does mean I go out to bars a lot and have basically tried every big beer bar in the Chicago. Hop Leaf is a legend if you talk to anyone that knows anything about beer. It was basically the first craft and European beer bar in the city and still boasts, in my humble and alcoholic opinion, the best draft lists around. Everything from rare US crafts to Belgium triples and always rotating. (Bonus points for always having Zombie Dust on tap like a boss ) The second reason I go to HL is the food. There is nothing on the menu not worth trying and everything I've ever gotten has been cooked to perfection and tasted as beautiful as it looked. The must try though are the mussels cuz damn son. Best mussels in Chicago (since Blue Bird closed). Their steak frites are also perfect. Head here on a date or alone to drink great beer and cry. This place is perfect.
Incredible beer selection. Start and end with 3 Floyds Zombie Dust! Bartenders are very knowledgeable and attentive. Sweet potato fries and muscles (not mine) are highly recommended.

For those of us who enjoy good beer, Hop Leaf is delightful, and the food is good enough to make even a non-beer-drinker very happy.  The beer selection is very extensive, and the description of each brew on the list is very detailed and helpful in making a good selection to suit your personal preference. Servers are also very well-informed on the subject, so I advise you ask for a suggestion of you are overwhelmed by the options. I've had several beers here and they have all been wonderful.   I've also never been disappointed by the food. The portions are generous and the prices reasonable. More importantly, it's super delicious. Best things I've ever had here include the duck reuben, the CB&J sandwich, and the fries. Sooooo good!
The beer list, the muscles in wine sauce, the ambience. Just love this place!! I recommend it to everyone

I love this place and have lived down the street for years.  The food is incredible, mussels especially and amazing beer selection.  I cant praise this place enough on the atmosphere, food and beer BUT the staff could be the most pretentious in all of Chicago. Always rude and always slow  but I guess its the price you pay.  If you are in a hurry, not the place to go. Half of the entire place does not have servers so you have to wait for usually the one bartender who is dealing with an entire room of guest.  On Saturday we counted over 40 guest in the back bar and only one bartender the whole time.   Its the busiest place in Andersonville and I believe the only Michelin rated, you would think they would staff accordingly.  But they dont.  I still highly recommend but plan accordingly.
Hopleaf's extensive, always-changing beer menu is a sole reason for visiting! Another, the mussels. Either preparation is delicious, but the mushroom is a personal favorite.

This place has an outstanding amount of beers to try on draft. Loved the selection. Had a ton of local brews. The one I loved was the Deschutes Fresh Squeezed IPA. It's one of my favorite beers. So good. The bar area is nice enough. Booth seating if you have a bigger party. Bartender was very nice.  The food there was good. I guess they are considered a Gastropub which means that normal food items must sound like they were crafted by a French culinary master and imported overseas. Just overly complicated. I got the... Organic Grass-fed Brisket--$13 on light rye; Montreal-style dry rub, slow-roasted while wrapped in bacon; w/stone-ground mustard, housemade dill pickle; pomme frites It was brisket on Rye sandwich bread and french fries. Pomme frites? FRENCH FRIES. There's really no reason for that. Plus, the french fries were okay. I couldn't discern anything that different between these pomme frites and other french fries I've ever had. Plus, the brisket was too dry for me, didn't taste the bacon infusion and didn't even realize there was mustard in it. Not a bad sandwich but when you make it out to be GRASS FED and Montreal Style dry rubs and all that, I expected it to be better than what it was. Although, not complaining for $13, still not a bad sandwich.  The ambiance in the eating area was nice though but, again, it felt like it tried too hard. Candles were on the table and soft jazz played while we ate. It was a nice atmosphere but there's something just about this gastropub thing I don't really get.  Overall, definitely check this place out. Maybe get some pomme frites while you are at it.

Out of town visit lead me to this craft beer haven. Well rounded selection with great menu descriptions along side a knowledgeable staff was reason enough to come twice and buy 4 glasses to take home!

CB&J sandwich for life! Came here for a couple of brews before going to Too Much Light. Loved the selection of brews and how they were broken down into regions. I liked that because it steered me to the appropriate place on the menu. As an out-of-towner, I wanted to get my hands on as many local brews as possible.  After we saw the show, we came back to this place. I spotted the CB&J and had to order it--cashew butter, fig jam, and cheese on pan-fried sourdough. I liken it to a gangatsa'ed up grilled cheese. I really dug this sandwich because that flavor combo would have never made it out of my brain and I now know that I want to replicate this at home.  The sandwich came with a side of Stilton mac and cheese and some house made potato chips. Those were both standard, and I do not mean that in a bad way. Those two side items are not particularly unique (like the sandwich) but were well done and tasty but something you can find in many restaurants.  Efficient and friendly service. The atmosphere is cozy with the use of low lights and little candles. The bathrooms are also poorly-lit, so be prepared for that if you have to make a trip.  Side rant: why does Chicago love ACTUAL flames in their little table candles? Where I am from, everyone has the fake tea lights. I am accident-prone so I was always super nervous that I would be placing a paper menu on a flame and then be the patient zero of the next Chicago fire. This rant has no bearing on the rating of this particular restaurant. This place was one of my favorite places that I visited while in Chicago.

Visited Hopleaf with two other couples - for beers & lunch. We all enjoyed the casual atmosphere. The waiter was very engaging and really "knew his stuff" about the different beers. He made some good suggestions on pairings with the food we ordered.  We all ordered different menu items - and everyone was pleased with their selection.  Will definitely return to Hopleaf this summer - imagine the outdoor beer garden is a blast!

Hopleaf is definitely one of my favorite "regular, go to" places. It's always on the top of my list when determining a place to grab a drink with a friend, or even a quick bite to eat. I'm not too much of a beer fan, but most of the people I hang with are, and the selection of on-tap beer is outstanding. They also have wine on tap, which is typically my choice. I have also tried the ciders, which are crafted to perfection. If you have a question or would even like to sample before making a decision, the servers are also accommodating and helpful.

It was a grey, slushy, wintery day in March...past the first day of spring.  I'd heard of the Hopleaf while I was living in Buena Park and never really had a chance to go despite the good reviews and then wound up moving north-ish to Canada.  As I had business in close by Uptown I decided to go to the Hopleaf on my own for a late lunch. Can I tell you that was perhaps one of the best decisions I made? The Hopleaf is a local Andersonville area favourite and from what I've read the reviews are bang on.  The place is deceivingly big, from what I understand it is a case of success leading to expansion. The entire place reflects the patient and rustic European (Belgian) way of life with a laid back feel like a part of the same village kind of vibe.  Walking in you sense there is a comfort level and a welcoming atmosphere, then walk into the second room in the back filled with old Belgian beer advertisements on brick walls which rise up two floors to a neo-industrial metal ceiling.  The upstairs terrase has piping for rails which work off well with the neo-industrial feel.  Back to the main floor there is a wonderful iron wood burning stove...just like you'd find in an old cabin.  The scent of the burning wood completes the atmosphere the owners have envisioned.  YES.  Take me away from reality and into a quasi-euro escape.  Only if it was sunny and warm enough to sit in the biergarten. The food was authentic, homemade, served in large portions, and made right.  I ordered a Seef Bier to go with my Duck Reuben and pommes frites.  The beer selection is primarily Belgian, and what a selection it is.  There are also beers from around the world that are inspired by Belgian brews, and then other beers. The Duck Rueben was made with Emmental cheese, sauerkraut, and nestled in between two slices of marbled rye bread, then grilled.  It was really a nice change from the usual Rueben.  The pommes frites were made to perfection, just as Le Belge would have made it.  Double deep fried (blanched and then fried again) to give it its crispy exterior and soft and tender inside. Delicious. The service itself was attentive, polite, and laid back...no pretense here.  The servers were dressed as they would themselves....no black t-shirts and black pants.  They don't pretend to be what they aren't and while pretty, the wait staff did not need to wear skimpy outfits.  Their atmosphere, service, and food does all that and more.  No need for cheap gimmicks. In the end, I ordered a coffee because I wanted to stay and linger just a little longer...to enjoy the nice atmosphere before heading back into reality.  The coffee was tantalizing to the nose in its beany brewed goodness and strong sense of a real - good - coffee.   Everything in the world is right again.  The snow has stopped and HOP-fully spring is around the corner so that I can enjoy that biergarten.

This is one of those places that you've got visit if you're in Chicago. It's got a ton of beer with high percentages of alcohol, and no children are allowed. There's no reservations, so you sit there while it's packed and drink away the time, so when you finally get your table, you've worked up an appetite with the beer so that when you get your amazing Belgian inspired food, you eat the whole darn thing in one sitting. This place is absolute madness on Fridays and weekends, so I recommend having something light to eat before you get to the dinner portion if you're planning on drinking while waiting. Parking is a little difficult to find, but easy to get through by public transit. I love the fact that it's a very adult environment- they keep their patrons happy with the food and the beer selections. I've been here a few times already so I would say anything on the menu is certainly going to be delicious. The only thing to keep in mind is the wait!
One of my favorite places in Chicago. They have a phenomenal beer menu and the food is amazing. The mussels are my favorite!

Food was much better than what I would've expected from a pub type place. Had a salad - the one with brussel sprout leaves - and it was so tasty.  Good thing to split unless you're going to have as a whole meal. I had the CB&J (cashew butter, fig jam, and cheese) which was everything that I would've expected. Savory and sweet, different but comfort food. The fries are amazing. My boyfriend never eats fries, but scarfed quite a few of these down. The aioli that came with was a perfect addition. Ketchup would've ruined them. One side of fries with a sandwich is enough for about 3 people to eat. Don't order an extra side. Will definitely be back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
Great beer selection? Check! Delicious food? Check! Mussels? Check! Check! Good service? Yes! The brisket sandwich is hard to beat, as are the meatballs and mac and cheese.
We had the mussels and frites-big portions and all open.  Draft beer selections are great!  Service was very good with helpful suggestions on beer and menu.  The oatmeal stout was great.
Good beer, food was good but a little pricey, but its Chicago don't like it move to Milwaukee.

You need to be 21 to enter, even if you don't want to drink alcohol. This is one of my favorite places in Chicago. Super chill, but not pretentious atmosphere. There is a restaurant area and bar area. Service is casual, but great. Suits this place. Great comfort food. Duck Reuben sandwich is so good. The fries that come with the sandwich are great. One order of Duck Reuben with fries is good for two people because the large amount of fries they give. We also had mac & cheese on the side. EXCELLENT. So good. I would eat that all day, everyday. GREAT beer selection. Decent price for a beer, sandwich, fries, and a side of mac & cheese. I have come to this place more than 3 times. Always so good. The fireplace they have is really cool.

Atmosphere: A Food: A Service: B+ Great experience, every time I have been there I ask myself why has it been so long.  The slight smokey smell from the wood burning stove, the lighting, the cozy table proximity--top notch.  The food and drink is just right, both in prep and presentation. The mussels are very satisfying and accompanied well by the extensive beer selection.  The service was relatively attentive, well informed and casual--all good.

So we all know the beer is great, but can we take a second to talk about the FOOD?! I had been many times for a great belgian beer, but recently went for lunch, and then two days later came back for dinner. Both were unreal.  I HIGHLY recommend the crispy duck leg dinner. It's a take on chicken and waffles that will blow your mind. We also split a charcuterie plate that was divine (we let our server surprise us, and it was wonderful). Everything was so great, I'm just disappointed I didn't save room for dessert! Service is excellent as usual, and a surprise bonus, we only had to wait 20 minutes for a table at 730pm on VALENTINES DAY! I don't know how they do their magic table-turning, but we were fully prepared to wait for over an hour and they squeezed us right in. This place is amazing.

Hopleaf is a pub I truly love. My reasons: 1. There is always a nice crowd there. Nobody shouts, nobody goes "duudee woohooo!! awesoooome!" etc. People are here to enjoy their drinks, food, and company 2. The place is not pretentious 3. Phenomenal fries and reuben. I also like the mussels. Oh, and the aioli work is impeccable 4. Great beer selection, around 40-50 beers on tap. Mostly Belgian styles 5. No TVs 6. Nice decoration, feels cozy but not divy or rundown 7. Plays Charlie Parker 8. Staff is very friendly PS: This place is listed as a gastropub on Yelp, but do not take it as: 'oh it is a gastropub, so they can charge me $12 for fries'. They are only $4 (or maybe $5). I enjoy going here in the evening, but also before the sunset to get some beers sitting by the window.
Don't be fooled by the pub/bar look. The food is solid.

The beer selection is amazing! Atmosphere is great for just grabbing drinks or for getting some food. I've only had the dinner there once, it was good. I'd say the main reason to go is for the atmosphere and drink selection though.

We had the brisket sandwich, pomme frites, and a few beers. Lots of options in the drink department, almost amazing. The brisket sandwich was a ruben without thousand island and sour kraut, the pickle wasn't dill, it was definitely bread and butter. Neither were really accurate on the menu, but that didn't make them any less tasty. The pomme frites however, were fantastic, hot, salty, all the great things that potatoes want to be. The service was very fast and atmosphere was excellent, go there just to hang out and have some great fries and a beer.

Their extensive beer list along with their delicious belgian ale mussels and frites with garlic aioli are why I always end up here at least a few times a month. The noise level can get a bit much on the weekends but the food and drinks make it worth the trip. Don't be afraid to ask the bartender questions about beer you're not familiar with. They all seemed very knowledgable and willing to help you choose one that you'll enjoy. I've even had a friend order a beer they didn't like and was about to send it back with no hassle from the waitress.

Their brisket is simply AMAZING. The aioli adds a fine touch to it. Incredible selection of stouts; their Guinness equivalent is much richer and smoother. The ambience transports you to a local pub in Munich: Tin signs written in German, flags of the German provinces and an incredibly polite and courteous staff. 5 stars!

Come for the beer, stay for the beer AND the food. This place does it all right. The beer selection is phenomenal and they have one of my favorites on tap: La Fin du Monde by Unibroue. For food, I had the Toasted Nueske Ham sandwich, which was an excellent balance of sweet and savory.  The place's ambiance is very laid back, and deceptively large. When you first walk in, you're in the dimly lit bar area with some seating, but there's two whole back areas with additional seating.  The service was great. Our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive, and our glasses were never empty for long.

On a recent visit to Chi-town I coudn't resist a visit to Hopleaf. We went at 4 to avoid the dinner crowd and were rewarded with prompt seating in the quiet back section. We started with a round of beer and cider from their massive and well curated beer menu. Against our waitresses recommendation we started with the croquettes which despite their lack of fishiness were crisp and tasty with great pine nut puree below and watercress above. For dinner we had two buckets of mussels which were fresh tasting and the two broth offerings were quite different and great for dipping. Next was duck leg and sausage which definitely highlightred the kitchen's skills. Duck is one of my favorite things and hard to get right. Their leg was crispy without being dry or fatty. The sausage was mild and paired well with the rest of the entree and the beer. Our final entree was the mushroom risotto which had great earthy mushroominess and was complimented by the fresh shaved brussel sprouts. It was not a creamy as it could have been but this is common in restaurants as continuous stirring for 20 minutes is usually not possible in a busy kitchen. They do rush you a bit but with the large following they have developed, tables are always in demand. It is also important to note that this is a bar and nobody under 21 is admitted.

I'm giving this four stars because my sandwich (catfish hoagie), as well as the sausage appetizer we shared, were absolutely delicious. Unfortunately, the sandwiches that my two friends got (duck reuben and organic grass-fed beef) were much less delicious.  The sausage appetizer was three sausages with a variety of sauces. While they were all good and intensely flavorful, I will say that it was incredibly expensive for the amount of food we got.  The catfish hoagie had a delicious amount of fish, a very flavorful sauce (although possibly a little too much of it) and a fresh piece of bread that was able to stand up to the weight of the filling. Their fries were also delicious - fresh, hot and just the right mix of crunchy and soft fries.  I found the duck reuben and the beef sandwich to be a little underwhelming - the flavors weren't very complex, and the meat itself was incredibly tender, but not particularly flavorful - especially since it was, purportedly, wrapped in bacon.  Overall: I would come back here, but I definitely wouldn't venture away from the catfish hoagie.

Well one magical night I was sitting at home in my bean bag chair listening to the sounds of the ocean sipping on my Shirley temple drink . That woman had some amazing movies. I can even do all the dances. Anyways I thought to my lonely self hmm I need a REAL drink something to TICKLE my Whistle and I went through all the yellow pages and even dabbled on the Internet and thought HMM. WHY not HOPLEAF so I changed my clothes and hopped on my Flintstone's tricycle and pedaled my brains over to HOPLEAF.  I was so Happy FINALLY I have found Glory the watering hole for the STARS. I took off my Smurf gloves and shook the bouncers hand and was happy I did that cause that shows RESPECT. I then went to the bartender and ordered but WHAT else A Shirley Temple. My eyes lit up like a Christmas tree and I nursed the drink for 3 hours while thinking and finished reading my favorite book the CAT AND THE HAT. This was to me one of the most glorious nights in my life.

The food and drinks are awesome, so is the atmosphere; the people I was with sat in the back and it smells like fresh burning wood; the two stars are primarily for the servers. Every time I took a sip of my drink, inching further and further towards the end, someone would pop up asking if I was finished and wanted my check. I get that it's the weekend, and therefore is considered a busy day for the establishment, but when someone is constantly asking if I'm finished with my drink, or every five minutes asking if I need my meal (sorry I was catching up with a friend, and trying to catch up. I will finish my food once I am done with this story. I am sorry) boxed up, it sort of sends the message that you want me gone. And wanting me gone doesn't make me ever want to come back to kick it, Hop Leaf. This review isn't being written by someone who has never worked in the hospitality industry, on the contrary, I have been a hospitality manager for years, which is why I was so frustrated. I don't know who has been training these folks to push folks out the door when they appear finished, but the general rule of hospitality is to be hospitable.

I'm so bummed I can't give Hopleaf more stars! I think my expectations were too high. But I will explain in this review and may edit it after I try it again. I came here on a Friday night around 7 pm with 3 other friends. I got there first to put our name in but there wasn't a wait. They needed my entire party to be there to seat us. Totally fine and understandable. This place gets crazy busy. And it was when I got there but was surprised at how big the inside was! They have 3 different bars I believe. One right when you walk in, another in the back to the left and then another upstairs. We sat directly in the back by the fireplace. Really cute and cozy. My rating is mainly based on the service from our waitress. It took her 20 + minutes to come take our drink order! So we just ordered drinks and food when she came. Ok, fine, it's busy. But she then only came 2 other times; to check on us and give our check. We were there for 2 hours! Unacceptable in my opinion.  The food was also just OK. I got the Duck Reuben. Good, but I definitely wouldn't order it again. And the fries were not that good either. What I loved the most were the mussels. Very tasty and I highly recommend! So, I will probably be back but just for drinks. The ambiance is great and the beer list... Hello?! Can't wait for summer to just sit on their patio with a beer :)

Two words....beef brisket!!  Oh and two more words....Mac n Stilton. Yum!!  Great place, chill atmosphere, decent service. Highly recommend it. We went at 6:30 on a Fri night and got right in barely but  missed the major rush. This place gets packed! And its a huge space, with a couple of bar areas and several dinning rooms. Pleasantly happy to see wine prices and choices, both on tap and bottle options so more than just amazing beer!

We like this place so much we have become regulars. However, we do not utilize the restaraunt portion of this venue: so this review is strictly for bar service. Which is EXCELLENT. All the bartenders are very nice and quick to answer any questions we have about the current beer selecton (as others have stated, changes EVERY week.) The mussles and frites are such a treat, I have tried the different broths and it is impossible to pick a favorite. If you want to be really indugent, try the "CBJ" sandwich. Don't question how cashew butter, fig jam and cheese go together...you're wasting time when you could be eating one of the most savory and delightful sandwiches ever...that comes with a side of home made mac & cheese, and home made potato chips...complete genius! If you want a more expensive entree, there are some delcious options even at the bar, so this is an easy place to take friends who all have different tastes and budgets. If you're at the bar (even seated at tables), there isn't a waitress. Go right up, order and start a tab. This makes it REALLY easy to do the separate check thing without akwardness. Hopleaf has easily become one of our favorite places to eat and drink in Chicago.

Pricey! but ooh so good. If you go in and have a beer and sandwich you can leave with money still in your wallet. If you are like me and want to try their frites and AWESOME aioli...and 10 beers.... it gets a little pricey. But hey, I have yet to really have a bad experience here. The food is great and the bartenders are AMAZING. I was having a horrible day and plopped down and ordered "whatever whiskey you'd drink" and I was served ??? who knows and went to pay for it, only to be told "don't worry about it." Love.
Some of the best beers in the city. Food is great, a little pricey but worth the money for sure, but honestly you can skip the food JUST for the beer.

Truly excellent beer selection.  Skews Belgian, but has tons of regional and national drafts as well.  Not a huge number of local breweries represented, but that's not really the point of this place. People throw the term 'gastropub' around a lot, but Hopleaf really nails it.  Elevated takes on pub standards with a continental flair.  Definitely on the heavier side, but all really good.  Never had any dish here I didn't want to have again.

Stopped in here not realizing that it was THEE Hopleaf that everyone always raves about. As soon as we sat down on a brisk mid afternoon day, I was already realizing we had walked into the right place. We were seated in the dining area, right in front of the wood-burning fireplace that was amazing.  We had just stopped in for a bite- we ordered the go-to's... the frites (french fries), onion rings (skinny and plentiful), as well as a pureed winter soup that warmed us after being outside in the cold. Highly recommended! Note to self: try the beer!!!

Let me start out by saying that Hopleaf is where I had a first date with the woman I'm probably going to marry, so it holds a very special place in my heart. So tonight we drank and dined with another couple and we were really excited to be back at the spot where we fell in love. We three seafood eaters ordered the mussels, which were divine...just straight up yummy. My girlfriend ordered the winter kale salad...but she wanted a bit of protein in it so she asked the waitstaff if she could have a poached egg on top. The server was very nice, but informed us, even after double checking with the kitchen, that they were not interested in accommodating special requests. We then asked if they had eggs, to which she replied yes. Are you kidding me!? We were both left dumbfounded. Being in the service industry ourselves, we could not imagine what kind of kitchen/management would uphold this sort of non- customer oriented service ideology. So, point of the story is that my girlfriend left hungry because your snotty kitchen wouldn't poach an egg for her salad....how tragic. Also, please advice your kitchen staff to use gloves or tongs when plating food...because walking by and seeing bare hands grab ready-to-eat food is vomit inducing. Do better, Hopleaf. Please do better.

We've only been for beer, and let me just say - the selection is amazing. So, please note that the review is only for beer. I had my first VanderMill cider herel, and I was not disappointed since I've been drinking it ever since. There's not a lot of vegetarian options and the place is a bit pricey, even for beer.  Note - No one under 21 allowed. Leave your minors at home. Overall? For us, come for the beer. You won't be disappointed.

For starters we had the charcuterie platter - I thought it was okay until I had the sausage in the platter and didn't like it all all!!!  Just to be fair my bf liked it  but of course I'm the one who is doing the review - oh well!.  After the appetizer,  I am so excited to have Montreal brisket in rye sandwich since that's the reason why we are there anyways.  Must I been building too much expectation to the sandwich ( a week since I saw the show featuring the restaurant) because I'm so disappointed. It's alright sandwich but I will replace it with any other bread over the rye next time . Hopefully I will be able to comeback and try the sandwich again just to make sure . Until then I will give them 2 stars .

Mann. If I would have known that this place was this good and this close to my house... I would have been coming to this place sooner! The beer selection was pretty extensive and our waiter was pretty knowledge - able and had really good recommendations on what I told him I enjoyed the most. We went on a double date and everyone but me got sandwhiches... my boyfriend had the duck reuben which was amazing but didn't had the ducky taste that I was expecting (roast duck) and could have possibly been a good thing. My cousin had the fish sandwich but I felt like I could have past on that one... but she did have the side of mac and cheese which was simple but good... I'm a sucker for baked mac and cheese it wasn't anything extravagant but didn't taste funny so it was good under my standards =P now on to my plate which was the pork chops... I asked the waiter what his favorite plates were and he stated that it was either the pork chops or scallops. And though I love scallops, the pork chops where calling me... and I LOVED every bite of it! No regret whatsoever. I found it nice that the waiter informed me that the pork chop is cooked medium rare unless otherwise asked but it didn't matter to me because if that's how the cook planned to prepare it.. then that's how I'll eat it! It was juicy and tender and didn't feel overwhelmingly too much... we actually ordered their fries with the aoli (sucker for aoli) after dinner because I was just OMG those fries... that aoli... my goodness... I can't wait to go back!

Based on the beer selection alone, Hopleaf is unparalleled for variety of amazing and hard-to-find Belgian beers. I really enjoy the fullness and roundness of a good Belgian, and this place has well over a hundred choices on draft and in bottles, some of which approach the cost of a fine wine! Reading the menu can take a while with the descriptions. The atmosphere is young with hip twenty to thirtyish people all dressed of the moment. That would be my only concern, insofar as the clientele is not nearly as varied as the selection of brews. There are two full bars here, where the one in the front is more of a traditional bar and the one on the other side with the floor to ceiling windows looking out on Broadway just south of Foster. I'm sad to report that because of local liquor laws, you cannot enter the bar even to eat unless you are 21 years old. We planned a family gathering there with a 17 year old nephew only to be turned away. Too bad! Be forewarned. Maybe next time I'll try some food. But then again, I know someone who only drank beer for a semester in college to save on food costs. She wasn't malnourished.

Hopleaf is by far one of my favorite drinking spots on the Northside. I generally go with a few buddies for drinks here and there. The layout is really neat and is definitely one of the better bars in Andersonville. They have a great range of different beers to choose from but the staff is hit or miss. I have gone on days were I wait 30 seconds for a drink and I have gone on nights where there was not to many people at the bar and was waited on for well over 10 minutes. It has a real hipster vibe to it but overall still one of my favorite places to go at spur of the moment.
This place is awesome. Read the other excellent reviews. My favorite menu item is the moules frites. Drink list is great, service is great. Crowded sometimes in the bar area, but that's life.

Great beers, tasty and hearty food, with a cozy interior. I've had a great time here, whether it is to bring an out of town beer lover or whether dodging in here for a quick afternoon beer and mussels appetizer. This is a solid beer and food place.

Still love this place and imagine my surprise when I went there with friends the other night, only to find that 2 years ago they doubled the size of the place!  Sweet! How could I have stayed away so long?  The service is still as friendly and knowledgeable, the beer list as impressive and the food still quite good. Also know that once they stop food service, you can pretty much sit where ever you want versus waiting to be seated by the hostess. Now if it was only not so far off my beaten path . . . . .

Went for the patio, which I hear is amazing.  There was a long line for it so we got a table inside instead.  The place is tight and windy, looks like the building used to be something other than a restaurant, but I really liked the way it looked.  We appeared to be pretty far from the servers but we had no issues with service. Great beer selection and the mussels were really good. Oh, and the doorman was reading a book as we left with a little light.  Pretty hip.

I've loved this place since before we moved to the area and now that we live a few blocks away, I love it even more.  Tonight I had kind of a bad experience: we got there and had a terrible time even ordering at the bar, then ordered fries that got delivered to someone else. Worst of all, the people who did devour our fries, were awful! But the bartender not only got us fries, but then comped our drinks! I've been here so much, and I'll be back again...and again and again. As someone who has spent a lot of time in northern France and Belgium, their draft selection is second to none.

Belgian mussels (portion for ONE is enough for TWO) , comes with fries and aioli. And is AWESOME. 99% of their beers are amazing choices, they had too many great ones to drink them all. Bartender was a bit preoccupied with some reps (bartender die apologize for ignoring customers) that were sitting at bar so he could have been more attentive- he was friendly though! I would give this place 5 stars if bartender wouldve attended to customers more. Overall awesome place and I would come back.

Atmosphere - great.  Food -  great. Large neighborhood local Belgium/German bar. Walked into the front to find a small bar area and very dark. Discovered that there's a very nice sit down restaurant in the back and then through another hallway another bar attached. Looks like this was once another storefront bought by this establishment.  The front bar was just okay but the rest was a pleasant surprise with the brick walls exposed and European decor. Very generous wine carafes with traditional wine glasses. We ordered two appetizers for our party of 4. The pome frites with mayo side dip and the German sausage served with potatoes and carmelized onions. You would have thought we had t eaten in days as we devoured it.     If you are visiting Chicago it's worth the trip out to Andersonville to experience

Aaaaaaamaaaaazing beer selection!  The food menu is small but mighty.  I went for the duck reuben and house made sauerkraut and it was heavenly - absolutely a perfect sandwich.  The fries also neared perfection and I loved the garlic aioli to dip them into. Service was great too.  If you like Belgian style beer, try the Tripel Karmeliet.  Spectacular!

Hopleaf was a nice bar.  Plenty of options for drinks.  The night we went it was rather quiet, which I'm not going to complain about.  The upstairs bar is the place to be.  Plenty of seating and cool atmosphere.  They don't take plastic, so b sure to bring cash!

I frequent the Hopleaf quite often, usually on a weekday night.  Trying to get a seat on the weekend is insane.  That said, I only have one complaint:  Their menu hasn't changed in oh, say, forever! This however won't discourage me from going, because you're guaranteed to find some obscure beer that will please you.  The owner(s) need to sit down with their chef and come up with some new menu items.

Last Saturday was my fifth trip to the Hopleaf and I've never once been disappointed.  There has always been at least a half hour wait to be seated, but last weekend (maybe it was the cold) we had a table right away. So, if you like beer, go here.  The draft menu is extensive.  It is a world tour of excellent American craft breweries as well as classic Belgian and German styles.  My brother in law & I really enjoyed some excellent beers.  We began with American IPAs to wet the palate, but then worked through at least 3 Belgian styles.   Take a cab. The food is good too.  I had the steamed mussels in white wine sauce for one, which come with Belgian style frites & mayonnaise.  One of the best nights of my life was in Bruxelles, dancing on tables at Le Corbeau, and then having great hang over sandwiches stuffed with fries, kebab, and spicy mayo.  Belgium knows how to party and Hopleaf brings us a little bit of that fun.  Go here.  I'll be back many times more.

Disclaimer: I came here to eat.  Ratings is based on food only. The beer selection here is beyond impressive.  The staff were super friendly and very good at making recommendations.  Personally I just finished running and just did not have the desire to drink.   We ordered the vegetable gratin and muscles.  The vegetable gratin was actually very good dish, surprisingly good.  We ordered a large serving of the muscles to share amongst the table.  The broth was good and the amount of muscles were good.  My only knock was some were still very grainy inside and they were tiny.   However, I will be back and will do an updated review when I come to have some of their beers.

My favorite and a must stop spot in Avondale. I've only been to the front room bar area (versus the formal dining room spot in the back). The beer list is awesome and a little overwhelming at first. GET THE SAUSAGE PLATE, the cheese plate was below average considering the price, quantity, and quality. Will return again.

Hopleaf is one of my favorite destinations in Chicago.  I talk about it to all my friends, to visitors, I go on special occasions and on Sunday fundays and any time I am craving a beer and have the money for an upscale but to-the-point snack (try butternut squash soup, stilton mac and cheese tho it's $6, or CB&J sandwich).   Next to Bad Apple, best beer list in the city.  Always rotating, always impressive, and always with accurate descriptions and knowledgeable bartenders.
Hands down the best bar in this neighborhood! I love love love this place. Get the ham sandwich! You will thank me for it!

This place is WAY over-rated.  The attitude of the staff is sub-par.  Seriously, there are much better places to get beer where you won't be treated like sub-human cattle.  Maybe some of the staff could SMILE???

Misinformed, snotty, pretentious wait staff. I enjoyed walking out of this place even though I had been looking forward to their beer selection all weekend. Won't be back here since there are so many other friendly beer bars in Chicago.

I'm not a beer person, but I am a Duck Reuben person. Well, at least I am now. Especially when the Duck Reuben is topped with tangy homemade sauerkraut and subtly sweet cranberry cream cheese that perfectly complements the brine of the duck. Don't get me started on the fries, skinny and salty and perfect. I could drink the accompanying aioli with a straw.

Hopleaf is a Chicago craft beer landmark, and yes, there should be a council that determines these things. If you have not been here or are visiting and craft beer is your thing, you have to go here. While brew pubs and microbreweries with restaurants are all the rage these days, Hopleaf has 20 years on them. This is THE place these breweries want all their new beer sold. What that means is you'll find the best beers from any and all breweries who sell in Chicago on tap at Hopleaf. Owner Michael Roper is as respected as anyone in the craft beer industry and he chooses only the most remarkable, intriguing beers from the most impressive, reliable and exciting breweries around the world. Even the most seasoned of craft beer drinkers will find something new every time they go to Hopleaf. It's the reason I never hesitate to venture back. On top of that, Hopleaf has managed to craft a menu that holds its own in Chicago's new American bar food scene. If you are a foodie who enjoys good beer, you're not sacrificing having a great meal in favor of beer selection. If you are into mussels, that's their big thing, but all their meat options are pretty excellent, especially the duck reuben, which is in its own league. And the frites! Addictive. The space is pretty labyrinthine because they bought and expanded into the property next door, but they have everything from party rooms to a back patio to a more contemporary open window dining room. Or you can sit in the original bar space, which maintains a close-knit dive feel. The wait staff has always been friendly and the bartenders knowledgeable. You can always taste any of the drafts. Also, it can get very crowded at peak times, so be mindful of that. Hopleaf is just a special place for Chicago beer drinkers and it's very inclusive of those who aren't bonafide beer nerds.

Beer nerds, rejoice! Hopleaf was a cool experience. Everyone I interacted with was very kind/helpful, and the beer selection is obviously out of control. Didn't see this on the menu, maybe I just missed it, but I would've loved to have done a beer flight. I will say I wasn't super crazy about the main menu in that all the courses looked ultra heavy. I would've gotten the fish sandwich but, Talapia, really? I mean I know you're frying it anyway but you couldn't spring for cod or something a little more palatable? Anyway, unable to decide on any one thing, I ordered the daily cheese plate and the charcuterie plate with headcheese, njeda and some kind of bacon. This ended up being the smart choice because it was delish and also light enough to where I didn't feel like I just ingested a ton of bricks.  My sister ordered the duck confit sandwich with pomme frites. I had a bite but all I could taste was sauerkraut (which I'm not crazy about) so it wasn't really for me. The pomme frites were great though! Overall, this place is great if you love trying lots of different kinds of beer and having a pretty unique dinner menu to choose from. Will definitely head back if I'm in the area.
My favorite gastropub in the city. The food is always great. The pommes frites are transcendent. The beer list is longer than Tolstoy. There's a nice cozy patio out back. Go eat here!

My boyfriend and I love this place so much it has become one of our regular places.  They have a great selection of beer and cider that rotates enough to keep things interesting.  I also love the ambiance - we always have fun people watching when we sit by the bar.  The food is also tasty and pretty creative for gastropub fare, if a bit inconsistent.  On the whole it trends towards tasty and well executed but I've also had some limp fries and mussels where the wine sauce just seemed "off" even though it had previously been very good.

Can't believe I never reviewed Hopleaf. I have been several times with friends and gfs but this is a pretty stellar first date location. You have tons of drinks options and you can go full dinner or just have nice little snacks. The frites are amazing. On my most recent first date here I tried the mussels for the first time and I regretted all the previous times I missed out on these. They're delicious and they come with frites! Two options available. I had the Belgian mussels.  I like the cashew butter and jelly sandwich. The duck sandwich is also great.  They have plenty of sides which stand alone like the Mac and cheese which I think uses Stilton.  The beer list here is outstanding. I'm not into beer but I do like cider and they have plenty of it! So that makes me happy.

Pulled in late after a late friday evening with TMLMTBGB down the street - the kitchen had closed alas, but we were able to sample many fine beverages.  They did not have schooner/taster glasses so we had to kill a bunch to sample broadly, as is our wont - seems like a legit spot, as many friends suggested.

Terrible service. Won't be coming back purely based on the experience I had here today entertaining friends from out of town. Go to monks, great drink selection and reasonably priced.. Unlike hopleaf. This was my first and last time here

Great atmosphere and decor. Because their name is Hopleaf, you expect great draft beers; that is what comes to your table. Food is pretty great too, and the pricing is moderate for the choices they offer. They need to get better with their staff in some aspects. They sometimes don't clear out empty glasses from time to time ( a little lazy). I'm still confident in the establishment and will return because of the great food and drinks.
Fantastic place. I wish I lived closer to it. The mussels are so good and the beer selection is just wonderful! highly recommended
Theyve expanded and improved. Great bar.
Too loud. The beer selection is good but it's difficult to enjoy your beer and manage to decipher what the friends around you are saying over the din. Chaotic scene on the weekend.

What happened to this place?  I used to love love love it, but after not having eaten there for a couple of years a recent visit proved disappointing.  The atmosphere was still cozy, the service was good and the beer list was still great, but the mussels were tiny and dry and the white wine sauce lacked flavor.  I remember sopping up the sauce with bread on previous visits.  This time I did not even finish the mussels, opting instead to quell the rumble in my stomach with the Fries.  Similarly, my friend's duck sandwich was more bread than duck and the kitchen's refusal to substitute regular cranberry sauce for the cranberry cream cheese to accommodate an allergy struck me as ludicrous.  Apparently they only make enough cranberry sauce to allocate to the venison meatball appetizer (which by the way was also pretty unremarkable) and spreading a knife-full on a sandwich would ruin their carefully portioned plan.  A visit here used to feel special, like you were in on an awesome secret.  Now it feels like a visit to a mediocre chain restaurant with a really good beer list.

This place just keeps growing while losing nothing in quality. Everyone knows about the extensive local, national and international beer list and it's as awesome as you've heard. Also a few hard ciders on tap and good cocktails. The food is more expensive than your average bar, but it's also fresher and more interesting. Not too many vegetarian options, but the CB&J is yummy. Get the Belgian-style fry basket! The servers are friendly and knowledgeable, and the place is beautiful with multiple levels and floors so it feels intimate despite its size. It gets packed, so go at an off time if you can. One of my favorite spots in the city.
I love this place for the beer selection alone. The restaurant is fine, the fries are good. But the beer. Yeah

A gastronomic gem.. I Have ALWAYS loved this place!  On a food front, this culinary team is cutting edge and always manages to put together tasty and unique dishes.  While I feel that I get a regurgitation of the same dish from many of the touted restaurants, I never feel that at Hopleaf.  And did I mention the beer menu?  One of the best in Chicago... this place has set the bar for the American Gastropub!

Drink selection: HUGE. Service: Decent Ambiance: could be brighter, could be less loud, but it's very laid back. Food: Heavy. All very heavy.  The mussels seem like their best item, but it doesn't really say much in comparison to the rest we've had. I mean, you can't go wrong with fries or onion strings and mayo, but all the food was just so greasy and heavy... Tip: If you're eating in a particularly loud area of the balcony on the second floor and want to stay for drinks, after your meal I'd request to move to the quieter bar section on the second floor near where the bathrooms are, because the difference is insane. You wouldn't have to keep shouting! Might come back with beer enthusiasts, but I'd definitely suggest we stop by for dinner elsewhere beforehand.

I can not believe I have not written a review on this place. It is my go to in Andersonville and never gets old.  It always feels like a treat. Ambiance: Walk in and you will have your ID checked at the door if its after a certain hour.  The front looks like your good ol' bar or English pub.  The back is where I enjoy my time.  Walk past the bar to the back and a server will find a space for you in one of their four areas.  The initial area where you walk in which is surrounded by beautiful brick walls.  The back patio that is lined with vines and takes you out of the hustle and bustle of the city.  Upstairs where you can lounge with friends and look below.  Or the newest area that allows you to watch the kitchen in action. Great for friends, a date, or a girls night out. Service: They have always been busy when I have gone.  I never found my servers extremely personable, but they had information for the table and kept it moving to accommodate all of the guests needs. Food: Delicious!  I always get the muscles and find it a sin not to indulge in it when I go.  They are the best in the city.  My boyfriend has had one of their salmon dishes.  It was good but a smaller portion that what he expected.  I have also had the Reuben.  Well done.  And that comes from a gal who usually does not do Reuben's.  The burgers are delicious as well. Drinks: I feel the wine is a little overpriced by the glass so when I go with the ladies I remedy that with getting a bottle.  The servers know their wine at this place, so just ask for a suggestion.  The selections are pleasing and solid. Price: Moderate.  Everything is worth it and it is a normal night out for dinner.  Probably around 15 - 19/plate.  Its worth it.  Feeling cheap get a 1/2order of muscles and you will be satisfied. This is my go to.  Make it yours as well

Pretty nice gastropub. Staff is very friendly and helpful. The draft selection is well diversified and it even includes draft wines. Food is what you expect at a gastropub and the quality is high level. I do recommend to visit on a weekday, as in weekends is a little wait. I didn't mind waiting, specially since I waited with a beer on hand. Lastly, the ambiance of this place is marvelous!

We mulled over a number of suggestions during my visit but my friend who lives pretty close said we should go to HopLeaf. It was SO yummy. We were going to sit at the stool area near the kitchen but my companion has been having some back issues so we went upstairs to wait and got some wine. (I will have to return and sample some of the beer/ale/cider available the menu is extensive and to be honest I was pretty overwhelmed) The tomato salad appetizer was really yummy-all the ingredients were fresh. My scallop appetizer was excellent. The scallops were seared perfectly and the sauce/plating stuff was really good. I pretty much licked my plate clean. My friend got a second glass of wine and the serving she received was pretty much enough for both of us. We had the mascarpone  basil cheesecake-also really yummy. I kind of wish we ordered a second dessert just to have more yumminess. The volume in the establishment was a bit loud so if you are looking for a super intimate environment this may not be your best bet but DEFINITELY seek it out otherwise.
It's pretty well documented how good this place is. I agree with any 5-star rating and disagree with anything less.  It can get crowded though.
I was super pleased with the beer menu... The food was a let down for me. I would come back for drinks, but not for dinner.

I went here Friday night with a small group for two friends' birthdays. We ordered a few appetizers to share (the onion rings really are outstanding), and each ordered an entree. We had a couple drinks each, and shared two desserts between the six of us.  The drinks were all good. The entrees were decent. The sweet potatoes anna that came with my very tasty Amish chicken were very weird. Every part of the entree was sweet, with nothing to balance the sweetness. Sweet chicken, sweet greens, sweet potatoes with cardamom or something that was just too much. Most disappointing was definitely the dessert. We shared two desserts between six people and they sat there half-eaten. Not one of us liked either of the desserts (the root beer cake, or the strawberry tart). I'm pretty adventurous, but the jalepeno cream with the strawberry tart was just gross. And the root beer cake was pretty dry.  Our waitress kindly took them off the bill, but let me just advise you, do NOT go here for dessert! I love the building and the decor is cute, and it's a great location, but the food really let me down. I don't think I"ll be back
Duck Reuben is perfect, and they had Zombie Dust on tap! Great service, tons of seating and rare beer on tap. Amazing.

Me and you, yo mama and Evan Hill too....well maybe not Evan he's too busy these days but hey you can come! I now consider myself finally a local of the neighborhood (it took a year and a half to adapt) but I have finally made my way to the best bar in the area. It took a while, but the wait was worth it. After making my way through all the hipsters, wanna be hipsters, starving and "way too good for you but nobody knows me" artists, and girls so independent and fancy "I'm married but still go to bars a flirt" or "can I borrow a smoke, oh you don't smoke whats wrong with you" bi girls I headed to the third floor. Big guys like me need the space plus I'm not a fan of paps and autograph hounds that exist in my pretend world. The beer menu is extensive and awesome while the food choices are not your average bar type items which i appreciate. i like trying new things and here you can do that with food and beers. Great place to bring some one cool you like (like Evan or other nice friends) or that cute girl who you've been trying to date for a while but she's still recovering from a broken heart and not ready to believe that your'e the guy who can change the way she looks at love for the rest of her life. I'm sorry I thought there was a 1000 letter limit on these.
Great place! Amazing beer selection - it's new all the time with unique brews that you won't get elsewhere. The food is delicious! I definitely suggest starting with their cheese platter.

We stopped here on a saturday night at 9pm with the bf and we were able to get a table immediately. The rest of the place was pretty full, so it was a nice surprise that we didn't have to wait. We were there mainly for pre-show drinks, but we did order the mussels with white wine and sweet corn. This was my second time here and I like the white wine and sweet corn broth more than the wittekerke white ale broth.. much more flavorful. The mussels are small, plump and juicy and their taste actually comes through. The frites and aioli that come with the order are super good, too. I'm not a big fan of mayo, but that garlic aioli is addicting. And their frites are thin, skin-on, and crispy.. yum.  The beer selection is huuuuge. We asked our server for a recommendation and it was amazing. Houblon Chouffe Dobbelen IPA Tripel is probably our favorite beer now.

It's all about "Duck Ruben" and a good beer. Well the sandwich was excellent, great combination of flavors, and what can i say "It's a duck". I'm not very big beer aficionado, i know what I like, and what tastes good to me. That said Hopeleaf has a great selection, but for the person like me it's a little overwhelming. Lots of hoppy  beers, many IPA's but I did not see any that I had a taste for. Don't get me wrong you will find something, you love beer you will have a great time trying different ones from all over the place. I have no doubt I will be back but I know I will have a hard time picking a beer that I will enjoy fully. One thing that I was disappointed with, were their Onion Rings. Really soggy and extremely thin cut, more like fried grass then onion rings, stay away from that.

Went here yesterday after hype of their mussels. We had an order if each of their two flavor of mussels(unimpressive...had to add stuff to it to make it taste better)..the pork belly appetizer, and octopus appetizer. Pork belly was awesome, the others--ehh. Had a rhone blend wine that the waiter recommended--I bought a cheap $3-$4 horrible bottle of wine once, and this was comparable to that. On a better note, they carry the ever so hard to find Three Floyd's Zombie Dust on tap, so kudos for that. Two stars.

Loud...Loud...Loud Very loud ambiance.    There is no table service in the first lounge area so you have to get your stuff at the counter and bring it to your table.    Beer selection is good...but can hardly have a conversation with your friends...

I love the hopleaf! The food is always great and they have an amazing beer selection!  Be warned that the menu  does not go all night, I don't know what their hours are in the kitchen, but I came in once at 11 and they had just closed the kitchen.  That being said, try the mussels! And the mac and cheese! And all the beers!

A friend and I had a wonderful lunch here on a Saturday afternoon. When the weather's nice, sit outside on their patio. Around 1pm, the patio was about half filled and the inside was less than 1/4 full. We shared the CB&J and the Duck Reuben. Both were great and I'd gladly eat either of them again, but the CB&J was our favorite. The CB&J is like a sophisticated hybrid of a grilled cheese plus a peanut butter and jelly. It's comprised of sourdough, homemade cashew butter, fig jam, and raclette cheese and is served with stilton mac & cheese (fantastic!) and homemade chips. The Duck Reuben is made with marbled rye, roasted duck breast, cranberry cream cheese, and emmenthal cheese and is served with frites and aioli. In case size matters to you, these fries are similar in width to those at McDonald's. Even though I typically prefer my fries thicker, I kept eating more and more so that I would have something to dip in the lush aioli. Yum. I'm not sure what the atmosphere is like in the evenings, but I think it's a perfect lunch spot to catch up with a friend, hang out with a group, or go on a casual date. I know I need to go back and try their signature moules frites... highly recommend!

Finally made it here after 4 years in the neighborhood and hearing numerous raves about this place, I have to say it was a disappointment. Upon arriving, the host and hostess told us it would be about a 20-30 minute wait for a table outside. We grabbed a drink at the less crowded bar upstairs and had a table within 5 minutes-great! Both of them were very pleasant people.  I ordered the toasted ham sandwich and the BF ordered the Duck Ruben, our food came out in a reasonable amount of time and was hot.  Unfortunately, it ended there. The fries that came with both of our sandwiches were covered in salt, so bad I couldn't eat them at all. Our server looked at me like I was nuts for asking for ketchup for them initially.  The ham sandwich was mediocre at best. and the Ruben was just okay.  Our server never checked on us after giving us the ketchup I asked for and last beer order. He really gave the impression that he couldn't be bothered overall. Also produced our check without asking if we needed or would like anything else.  Big disappointment overall, I don't care how great of a beer selection they have-I will not be returning.
Beer selection is exceptional...Food is also superb.  This place doe not disappoint.  Staff is friendly and attentive.  Added to my list of favorite places in Chicago.

I don't always post but I think this should be mentioned here and on their website, no Kids are allowed. Not even to go and eat lunch with parents. So if you have a 20 year old kid, unfortunately they need to be left home since it's 21 and up establishment...
Such a great restaurant. Extensive beer menu. Had a duck Reuben that was awesome and the fries were ridiculously good. My daughter had the cb&j - a gourmet , grown up pb&j that was amazing.

Let me start off by saying both the food and bottle selection were excellent. Unfortunately our server's attitude was inexcusable.  The first beer I selected was unavailable. No problem, it happens, and the server recommended a similar beer from The Bruery which I knew to be excellent. However, when I explained that I came from California and would like to try something more local, he seemed inexplicably offended. Ok, not a big deal...some people take their craft beer seriously. The beer I ended up with was decent, and the Urthel quad I selected afterwards from the bottle list was excellent. The food was also superb, and the portions generous; we split the Peking duck Reuben and the brisket, with a side of Mac n cheese. While we were eating, we noticed that the couple next to us had been trying to get their check for awhile, but the server was nowhere to be found. Glad we weren't in a hurry too. A busser noticed out food hadn't been touched for awhile, and promptly boxed it up for us. Afterwards, we noticed our server flit through the far side of the room, glancing at our boxed and bagged food, yet not coming over to our table (or anyone else's). We waited for about another twenty minutes without seeing the server before flagging down the host and asking for a check.  He tracked down our server, who finally appeared from the back (not carrying food, drink, or a check or anyone else either), then brought us the check. When my girlfriend attempted to hand him her credit card without looking over the receipt, he waved it in her face and said "just so you know I didn't charge you for six briskets". Unbelievable...I didn't know that credit card fraud was something we should be worried about at this restaurant. Now we'll have to keep an eye on the credit card statements because at least one person on staff at Hopleaf cannot be trusted. What a shame.

Great environment and beer selection! Disappointed that every time I have eaten at Hop leaf, the food has been terrible!  At first glance everything on the menu sounds great, but its always too fried or buttery. And the salads come out with hardly any toppings and tasting plain. Lesson of the day: Great for drinks and fun! Terrible for dinner!

The best possible combination: absolutely incredible craft beer selection from all over the country and the world + delicious slightly non-traditional gastro-pub food.  You won't find a reuben sandwich here - you get a duck reuben. You won't find generic thick steak fries - you will find a mountain of thinly cut Belgian style pommes frites. Prices are quite reasonable but you will likely be spending a good amount of money here based on all the beers you'll enjoy trying.  It will be crowded on weekend nights - the scene is lively, the space (two-floors) is aptly decorated as a beer-focused pub.   This is the kind of place you go back to to try. It is impossible to properly enjoy the vastness of Hopleaf's beer and food selection in one night.

the cbj was 5 stars! however, the rest was just good. we got the white wine mussels and they were good, but nothing amazing. we also had the pork belly and i would suggest skipping it.  my husband had the ribeye and it was good, but nothing special. the pomme frites were awesome and the aioli was out of this world. i don't like mayo at all but this was not your regular mayo. going back to the cbj, it was the star of the show for me. if you have never had it, do yourself a favor and get it! i will be getting the duck reuben the next time and trying the mussels in the beer.

EPIC beer selection - doesn't even cover it.  The cooler on the side has beers I've only read about and lusted after.  This place is mecca for the Windy City hophead.  I'm not a big wheat/belgian fan, but their selection is truly formidable. Did I mention they serve food?   Fantastic, rustic dishes.  I had a meat appetizer with head cheese and more - where else are you gonna get that?  For my entree I had the rabbit.  It was cooked PERFECTLY - not overdone/underdone like 90% of the time folks try to prepare it. Service was stellar, my cup runneth over.  Check it out!

Awesome beer bar. I mean awesome. If you are into beers at all, this place is worth the trip up. And even if you aren't super into beer? Well this place is a rarity in that it also has pretty amazing food here too! I mean it is Bib Gourmand (Michelin) recommended, and how many beer spots can claim that title? Ya, like none.  You walk in here, and it is a little dark inside, but there is a big bar area, some tables and booths, and it is all wooden and you can tell you are in a beer bar instantly. Then you discover there is a whole outside world to Hopleaf with an amazing back patio with all kinds of sunshine, and all of a sudden, my drinking atmosphere comes to life. A little outdoor drinking, really fancy bar food...yup. We got this amazingly constructed shrimp salad dish that was stacked like a magical tower that was pretty tasty. And then we also got a bowl full of their muscles which were some of the best muscles we have had in a while--so much flavor. And order the muscles for one and it is still an army of muscles to eat! I couldn't imagine how muscles for two would even fit on the table. And the slow roasted duck reuben sandwich was also pretty awesome. We ordered too much food for sure for the two of us (plus add on a few beers each too of course!), but every bite was well worth being full forever afterward. We will definitely be back.

I cannot write enough good things about Hopleaf. If you enjoy good beer, great food, and conversation with friends, then this is the place for you. A quick rundown: dozens of beers and ciders on tap (many Belgian), a long bottle list, glassware that matches each beer, delicious food (the fries are very salty if you like that), intimate atmosphere, ample seating.

CB&J..on point, yet! Enjoyable atmosphere and not rushed. The outside area was comfortable and shaded enough that I didn't even have to wear my sunglasses, which is always a plus when with company. Looking forward to going back.

Came a while back for a friend's birthday. We were a very large group and the front area is self seating/no reservations and you must order everything at the bar and we managed the entire night. It was good and fun. The duck sandwich is to die for and I'd go there just for that. The beer here is yummy as well and there's a wide selection of great stuff. If you are nearby and have the chance GO!

- A star for the lack of wait on a Saturday night! We were seated immediately (when does that ever happen!!?) - A star for the beer list: the first time my eyes laid upon it, I almost shed a tear. - A star for the food-- The CB&J really is as good as they say, good god. (so is the brisket. umf.) - A star for our lovely server (who gave me a side of their delicious aioli to go!) - A star for the atmosphere/décor (hella chill, so much yes) I could not ask for a better dining experience. See you again soon, Hopleaf ;)

Interesting menu selection. I had the tilapia sandwich with frites and it was phenomenal. It had just the right amount of crunch and satisfied my craving for fish. We sat upstairs so we were able to look down on the bar from where we were sitting so we had a great view of the whole restaurant. I recommend this place for dinner and will be back soon.

Amazing selection of beers from around the world, great selection of Midwest craft beers & great great food! Have been here a few times and tried the mussels special (they change frequently), the mac & cheese and some of the sandwiches-- would recommend any of them. Last time I was here, my sister tried the corn bread entree which seemed odd for an entree, but that was good also. Food is consistently great, and will definitely keep coming back for the food & beer.

One of my favorite spots in the city! Beers from all over the world. Never had a bad dish, the mussels are a must. Love that their menu rotates. Get there early, I don't believe they take reservations and the wait is always long.
Their rotating beer list has one of the best selections and some of the most affordable prices in town.

I sat at the perfect table (see photo), on a perfect summer evening and had a perfect meal. That it was just a sandwich and fries makes it that much more impressive. The duck rueben was one of the best sandwiches I've ever had, and one of the best meals at all I've had in a while. Quality ingredients, creative, we balanced recipe, perfectly executed. Excellent fries and sauces. Great dinning experience. Perfect atmosphere.

What a fun space/atmosphere with such a great beer list, and awesome food to boot. My red pepper soup and side of bourbon/pancetta beans were really fricken good (and really reasonably priced!), and my friends' mussles and frites were just as delicious as advertised (and you get sooooo many frites). If I were a local, this would definitely be my local spot.

I wish I could give this place 10 stars. One of the best craft beer pubs in the Midwest. Meaghan and Charity are awesome and welcomed this California kid with smiles and Zombie Dust. 5 stars for the food too. In love with HopLeaf.  RA
Great selection of beers. I wish I had explored the place, because it's so much bigger than it looks on the outside.

Friends were celebrating birthday at hopleaf tonight. I live out of town but I called to see if I could buy a round of drinks for them. Manager was very cool and accommodated request, and I even got a call back with update.  I appreciated their help in helping me surprise my friend on her birthday.

Hopleaf is delicious!! They have a huge selection of beers, a great ambiance, and really good food. I usually get the steak and fries and it's always great. The fries come with this sauce that I'm basically obsessed with. I only wish they had a bigger food menu, but the food they have is great!
